DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Small Business: Unfair Dismissal Legislation Questions on Notice

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to briefly speak on two matters tonight. The first is to comment on the Senate decision last night in regard to the unfair dismissal law and to say what an outrageous, disgraceful decision that was by the Labor Party and the Democrats. Today in question time it was raised, and the matter of their knowledge of small business was thrown around the chamber. The reaction from the other side was quite incredible when you think about it. I sat there and I looked down the list of the people sitting on the front bench, and I thought, `Well, it is probably no surprise that they do not really understand small business and they do not really understand what we are about and how important this particular amendment is to the very small businesses.' I looked along the front bench. I will not name them but I wrote them down. If I look along the front bench of the other side, I see the first person: background, union politics; second person: background, teacher union—
—Name them.

—You know where they sit; starting from the left and moving along. Third person, Public Service; fourth person, union; fifth person, union; sixth, union; seventh, academic; next, academic politics; the next, Public Service; union; union politics; union politics; union politics; Public Service politics; union politics; union politics; academic. That is the front bench of the other side. No wonder they have got no understanding of why it is important to get the sort of change that we wanted. Certainly all the small businesses in Eden‐Monaro from the chambers of commerce that I have been going to over the last couple of months are quite incredible in what they say about industrial relations and the fact that the Labor Party and the Democrats do not understand. I am encouraging all those businesses to put it in writing and tell these people why this has to change. But I do not hold out any hope, I am afraid. When you look at that sort of background on the front bench, they would not have a clue.

BREAK.PARA: The other matter I want to speak on in the adjournment debate tonight relates to answers to questions on notice in the back of yesterday's Hansard. The first couple of questions are very interesting. The first two questions were from the member for Werriwa, Mr Latham. The first relates to the cost of running the Lodge and Kirribilli House. The second relates to the cost of running the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard)—the staff, staff travel, car allowances. Given it has been a pretty topical thing in the last few weeks around the country, I thought it was quite interesting.

Clearly, the member for Werriwa thought that he was being quite smart in asking these questions. He thought that he was going to expose some enormous expenditure because the Prime Minister has his base in Sydney—even though we all know that the Prime Minister has to be where the Prime Minister is and he would probably spend just as much time in Canberra, Melbourne, Adelaide and wherever else he is required to be. It is quite irrelevant when it comes to cost.

The expenditure is rather interesting. The Prime Minister in answer gave a comparison between the first full year of the coalition government and the last full year of the Keating government. The recurrent funding is the main one, but we will give all the costs. The total cost of the operations of the Lodge and Kirribilli House in the first full year of the Howard government was $3.434 million. In the last full year of the Keating government it was $3.74 million. So it is over $300,000 more.

The recurrent funding is probably more typical for comparison. Under the Howard government it was $2.969 million as opposed to Keating's $3.613 million. They are the chardonnay socialists—the Bollinger Bolsheviks, as somebody said.

If you look also at the staff costs and staff travel—those opposite supposedly would make merry hell of all of these things—you will find that the total cost of travel for staff under the Keating government in his last year was $312,000 as opposed to $151,000 under the Howard government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Half.
—Half. In this current year, the total for the Howard government for a particular period of time was $500,000 and $760,000 for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley). (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about the Department of Veterans' Affairs and what seems to me to be a preoccupation with rules and regulations rather than outcomes. In the past couple of weeks, two separate but unrelated cases have come across my desk in which a couple of constituents have been penalised simply because they did not follow the rules and the bureaucratic procedures to claim entitlements which otherwise would have flowed.

SPEECH.PARA: The first involves an 84-year-old blind ex‐serviceman—he happens to be the brother of a former colleague, Senator Reg Withers—who required surgery. Unbeknown to this gentleman and his local medical officer, who happened to be a locum at the critical time, it turned out that, under the rules, the officer should have advised the Department of Veterans' Affairs that the patient had elected to be treated in a private hospital in Western Australia. Had he done so, this locum, unfamiliar with the rules, would have been advised that authorisation would not be given because the same service is offered at Royal Perth Hospital, which is a public hospital.

Despite the fact that he had a legitimate claim and a legitimate condition which would qualify him for treatment, he was denied any sort of support whatsoever in the end. The LMO admitted his oversight. Of course that became the basis for a lack of entitlement. It also leaves me and my constituent incredulous. He could have sued the doctor for negligence, but he is not that sort of bloke.

Despite my request to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) to exercise his discretion in the circumstances, the minister's response was to observe that there is no record to indicate that the patient followed the correct procedure and that, therefore, under the terms of the treatment principles he is unable to assist in this situation.

BREAK.PARA: The second instance concerns a fairly recently widowed woman who is being denied her claim for a funeral benefit following the death of her husband. She is being denied this assistance not because her husband did not die and not because she did not qualify for the benefit but because she did not apply for it within 12 months.

It appears to me that, for someone to successfully claim for this entitlement, they have to make representations to the department within a 12-month period following the death of his or her partner. However, there is nothing on the application form to indicate that that is required. Nor did department personnel advise my constituent of the deadline when sending out the application form.

The woman has received professional advice that, had her claim been submitted within the recognised time frame, it would have been approved. When your spouse dies you probably are in no condition to think about those things. At a time of great personal sadness, she had to deal with a department hell‐bent on following correct procedures.

Given the slightest opportunity, the minister in this place goes to great lengths, with some justification, to advise us of the professional and compassionate approach his department takes when dealing with its members. I regret to advise that what he avoids to say is that this compassion is extended only to those who subscribe to all the rules and all the regulations of the department.

In the two cases I have just referred to, the department is sending a clear message to all ex‐service men and women that departmental procedures take precedence over the entitlements which otherwise would apply to an individual. It has been indicated on not one but two occasions that, should anyone not observe the guidelines, the rules and the silly and petty little requirements, they can expect to be met with a bloody‐minded, `You failed to adhere to the correct procedures.' They are given a `there is nothing to be done' type attitude. That is simply not good enough.

I accept that there is a need for rules and regulations, but when you are talking about the diggers you have to be a little bit more sensitive, and that is not coming through. The minister is great with his policies and with what they have done since he has become minister. But, in the administration of the day-to-day rules, this is the sort of bloody nonsense that my constituents have had to put up with. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Randall, Don, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to report to the House on a matter of grave concern in New Guinea. Recently I returned from a parliamentary visit to the South Pacific. The matter I wish to talk about concerns Rosemary Gillespie, who is well known to this country through her activism in the South Pacific and her current role in Bougainville, which has been going on for some time. I believe I am supported on the crossbenches on this because I have newspaper cuttings here which have Gareth Evans, Martin Ferguson and Bob Hogg when he was here also coming out and slamming Ms Gillespie's role in this region.

SPEECH.PARA: Ms Gillespie considers herself a human rights campaigner. She is a law graduate from Monash, et cetera. Before I go on further to talk about Ms Gillespie I must give the background. In 1987 she was arrested and deported from Fiji for trying to involve herself in the internal matters of Fiji. She was also arrested in Vanuatu in 1994, and she has been involving herself in Bougainville since 1992.

The big problem with this is not that Ms Gillespie is not compassionate—I would give her a chance to say that that is some of her motivation—but we know that a few weeks ago at Burnham in New Zealand the New Zealand government and Australia flew representatives from the BRA, Bougainville and Papua New Guinea to New Zealand to try to resolve the Bougainville problem. We know that that problem revolves largely around Francis Ona, the Panguna mine in Bougainville and trying to resolve the large number of deaths and conflict in that situation.

This is coming together. The ministers and members that we met on our delegation in New Guinea were able to tell us that it is progressing towards a resolution and they are heading towards an autonomous government on Bougainville, not an independent state like Ona wants but an autonomous government eventually. That is a huge leap forward from where they have been on this matter.

I refer now to the problem with Rosemary Gillespie. She has visited there frequently. She is an enemy of the state of New Guinea. I have a headline here that says `PNG may try a lawyer in her absence'. I have a whole heap of these cuttings here. She will not go through the normal channels in Papua New Guinea now. She goes through the Solomon Islands, through Honiara, which is very close to Bougainville. She puts a lot of people's lives at risk. She has been saying that she has been taking medicines there. If she has, that is good, but there have been other allegations about what she has actually taken there, and that includes arms.

This is a very dangerous situation because, with this peaceful resolution that they are heading towards in Bougainville, Francis Ona is being isolated by the BRA because of his extreme position. The BRA is coming to a point where they would like to resolve it. There is a lost generation of children there who have never been to school in their lives. I am told that they are young, gun-toting kids who have never had an education. The health system has broken down. The whole fabric of society has broken down in Bougainville because it is lawless and they cannot get aid in there. There is a situation of conflict the whole time.

Probably one of the most alarming things is that people thought that Rosemary Gillespie had dropped out of this situation, but it is not true. I am informed that she returned last year with her daughter Kirrallee at some grave danger to themselves because of the antipathy towards her role in dividing the Bougainville situation. Many members of the BRA say that she is not welcome there.

The problem is that it is also causing problems for Mr Ona himself. I am told that she is back in Australia now, but she is in continual contact with him by satellite phone. New Guinea would like to see her out of the situation and stop this troublemaking in the South Pacific and Bougainville so that this matter can eventually be resolved. I ask the Australian government to take more notice of these subversive activities of Rosemary Gillespie in Bougainville, otherwise peace will not come to that island.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, before I begin, I wish you a happy birthday. I understand it is your birthday today.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had a fine example in this House during question time both today and yesterday of the complete incapacity of the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) to get a grasp on his portfolio. A reporter for the Sydney Morning Herald, Mike Seccombe, said today that the minister was floundering about like a fish out of water, looking strikingly similar to that former leader of the coalition, Dr Hewson, when he lost the plot explaining how his GST would affect the sale of—remember it—the humble birthday cake.

Just as that failure of Dr Hewson's was a crucial turning point in the community's acceptance—or should I say non-acceptance—of the GST at the 1993 election, so too has the minister's faltering performance over the past couple of days convinced Australians that all is not well in the way of aged care reforms.

Now the minister faces another challenge—a poison pill after being handed the poisoned chalice, as the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) put it during the MPI today. It relates to his decision yesterday to defer changes to the system of child-care payments until Easter next year—an admission to all and sundry that the government does not know what it is doing and is in danger of plunging the administration of child‐care payments into a nightmare world of complexity and complication.

The minister has said that the delay is simply because he has listened to `the concerns of the community'. What a laugh! If his government was listening to the concerns of the community, he would still be the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and not stepping over the political carcass of the previous Minister for Family Services and trying to make a purse out of a pig's ear with the government's aged care reforms.

In relation to the changes in child‐care payments, both parents and the child‐care industry are scratching their collective heads over the government's intentions. None of the changes have been adequately explained. When people call the department for clarification, the public servants whose job it is to explain these matters are unable to help. They have been kept in the dark as to what is involved and they just do not have a clue.

I am beginning to feel a sense of deja vu about this whole situation. I seem to remember a similar chain of events occurring in relation to the aged care changes when the previous minister for this portfolio was in charge. Those changes were meant to come into effect on 1 July, but because of the previous minister's incompetence, because of her failure to get the system working smoothly and to adequately inform the aged care industry, pensioner groups and even the department's own staff about the changes they had to be postponed until 1 October, not that such a delay has done the government any good.

I fear the government is sailing down the same tortuous path in relation to child‐care payments. The people in the child‐care sector and the parents in the community recognise the same fact. To illustrate this, I recently received a letter from a gentleman who operates several preschools in my area, a Mr Larry Rundle.Mr Rundle articulates the confusion shared by so many of his fellow members within the child‐care industry. In particular, Mr Rundle feels the government has not done enough to tell people in his position—via the body which will be responsible for administering the payments come April next year, Centrelink—about the government's new priority system of child‐care payments.In a nutshell, Mr Rundle wants to know how much financial assistance parents using his child care centres should be expecting. Mr Rundle writes:
Centrelink cannot tell me whether non working parents will be allowed 2 days care or 20 hours care.
Centrelink cannot tell me what a priority 1, 2, 3 or 4 is, as they have not dealt with this system before—
They have no knowledge of it. He continues.

If Centrelink cannot tell what constitutes a priority 1 or 4, I cannot tell parents: (a) how much care they will be entitled to in 1998; (b) I cannot explain to parents how to become a priority 1 rating so they can access 50 hours care for their child; and (c) I cannot help educate parents regarding studying, looking for work, etc, to coincide with this priority system.
He goes on:

These major problems make it impossible to take placements for more than 2 days and a large number of children are coming 3 and 4 days and do not know what it is in store for them and some of these parents may already be eligible for 50 hours.

From his letter, Mr Rundle's frustration and confusion is palpable. So far, neither the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) nor his predecessor has exhibited any intention of adequately explaining these changes to people in his position. I am glad to see the delay in the implementation of these child‐care payments. However, if that is all it is—a delay—without any of the work that needs to be done to explain these changes out there in the community, if it is going to be another nursing home entry fee debacle, then I do not know hold out much hope for Mr Rundle's sanity or his business.

The Minister for Family Services has a lot of pressure on him at the moment—pressure he is willing to shoulder. In the short time he has been in the job he has not filled anyone with any confidence—certainly not his own team members who are not rushing to his support. He is going to have to do some heavy work over the next seven months to make sure that child‐care payment changes are adequately explained to people like Mr Rundle and to parents around the country. If he does not, come next Easter, he will find himself in a similar situation to the one he is experiencing now.

I have already made written representation on behalf of my constituent because he has so many concerns over the area of child care. His second concern—and I will not have enough time to put it here tonight—is one that is just as dangerous for the industry and could force many of them into bankruptcy. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very appropriate that I am following the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio). I intend to read into Hansard a letter from the Aged Care Organisations' Association of South Australia, representing the non‐profit organisations in the aged care industry in South Australia, to the editor of the Adelaide Advertiser that, hopefully, will be printed tomorrow. The news release is headed `Nursing home media fiasco'. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Has anyone at all given thought to the damage this scaremongering campaign is doing to the many wonderful organisations in South Australia where staff and conditions are of the highest standards. Where care, nursing and love is given unstintingly as a matter of course?

What of the morale of these organisations and their staff. What is this doing to the hard won reputation of fine Nursing Homes and Hostels who base their culture around the needs of people in their care. Current residents and families are looking on in dismay, concern and disbelief and their words of reassurance are simply not being listened to.

The `poor' nursing homes who have been targeted these last two evenings on television, are small in number. However, even two or three are too many, and the sector is comfortable, indeed gleeful, that the new government arrangements are attempting to weed out these poor performers.

Yes, there are problems with the new arrangements. Problems that our Association have been discussing, arguing and negotiating with the government on, for almost a year. The cost in time and dollars to the industry over this period could not be estimated.
But the community must stay calm. The politicians are now playing games—the media joins the fun—and the frenzy begins!
Not hard to see who are the losers!
Then they try to dispel some of the more gross misrepresentations, saying:

The Accommodation Bond is a loan to the facility. Only $2600 can be kept each year to a maximum of 5 years, ie $13,000. If a resident stays 1 year, and pays $50,000, they, or their families receive back $47,400.
The interest on this money is used for building upgrades, safety standards, and maintenance.
The lady writing this poses the question:

Where else can organisations find the huge dollars required to upkeep and upgrade their buildings? Over the last several years of . . . governments, capital funding has diminished and is now practically non existent.

Entry Contributions (Bonds) were introduced into Hostels around 10 years ago and have been utilised by Hostels throughout SA over this period. The Church, Charitable and Community owners of Hostels have been prudent in their management of these Bonds, and used the interest wisely.
Result: Hostels generally are of a far higher standard than Nursing Homes.
People want to see their loved ones in a pleasant and warm home like environment.
Only those who can afford to pay an Accommodation Bond are asked to do so. Levels vary according to the organisation and the financial status of the incoming resident.

Most not for profit organisations carry far in excess of the mandated level of financially disadvantaged people. People and their needs are utmost. Some organisations in SA carry 40%, 50% and up to 90% financially disadvantaged people. Their finances are finely balanced indeed!
Residents do not have to sell their home. There are a number of protections in place and a periodic payment scheme is available as an alternative.

However, 99% of single people entering a Nursing Home or Hostel do not want to keep an empty house, with all its financial implications, when they are in care. It is a hassle for them and their families. In 99% of cases it is simply the sensible solution.

In conclusion, Mrs Ros Herring, the Executive Director of the Aged Care Organisations' Association (SA & NT) Inc., representing 84 nursing homes, 139 hostels, 81 retirement villages and 29 providers of community and home care services throughout South Australia and the Northern Territory says:
Come on media—
and she might as well have added `come on politicians'—
This is not fun! This is vulnerable people and their lives and their concerns and their care that is being misrepresented so appallingly. How about bringing some reason into the arguments?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 10.00 a.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Mr Fahey:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Randall, Don, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak today on the Airports Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 which will facilitate the second phase in the sale of federal airports. On 1 July 1997 we saw the first phase of the sale of Federal Airports Corporation entities—Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth airports. Naturally, I have a very keen interest in the sale of the Perth airport, because it lies within my electorate.
—Your electorate is well represented.

—Thank you very much. I also have a genuine interest in the other airport sale in Western Australia—of Jandakot airport—not only because it adjoins my electorate but also because I was—before my time as a member of this House—the chairman of the planning committee of the city of Belmont and also the deputy member of the Perth airports municipalities group, which takes both of these airports as their main business.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that the Perth airport was sold for $643 million to Airstralia Development Group, and the revenue raised here adds to a very efficient and substantial privatisation package, along with the revenue raised by the sale of the other airports. We are all going to benefit from the revenue raised and we are all going to continue to benefit from the excellent manner in which Australian airports are being managed privately.

In my own state of Western Australia, the Perth airport remains under the good guidance and management of Graham Muir who steered the airport's operations while the FAC controlled it. As I have said previously, I am very pleased to see that Mr Graham Muir now heads the Western Australian airports group.

This same airport has recently won an award for excellence in airport management and operation, and this highlights the success of privately owned and run airports compared with publicly or government owned airports.

Recently, I met with Westralia Airports Corporation and they broadly outlined their proposed management plan which has very strict regulations to ensure that the concerns of local residents and businesses are taken into account during the operation and further development of the airport. These regulations encompass many areas of airport operation: environmental and heritage concerns, construction and development laws of local and state planning authorities and, of course, aircraft noise and traffic management. In fact, there is plenty of evidence to demonstrate that the new private owners of the Perth airport, as indeed of other airports around Australia, are managing their airports productively and efficiently but, most importantly, in a responsible manner.

There are many good examples of privatisation and private ownership. In fact, the previous government, as we know, involved themselves in the sale of Australian Airlines, Qantas, and the Commonwealth Bank. I would ask anybody to challenge the fact that these entities are being run, if not more efficiently, then certainly as efficiently as they were before. In fact, the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) would know that there was a hue and cry when the Midland workshops were sold and privatised in Western Australia so that you would have thought that the world, as we knew it, would end.

However, the business that was being done at those workshops is now not only being done more efficiently but is also benefiting many people. Companies like Gemco have provided an excellent service, and we do know that privatisation is not all bad. In particular, this was something that was proposed by the previous government, so it is with pleasure that I welcome the government's phasing‐in of the second round of airport sales, where the airports will be offered for sale by way of long‐term lease or, in some circumstances, on a freehold basis.

I am going to refer to Jandakot airport in particular because it is the airport that is in Western Australia. However, I need to put on the record at the beginning that this bill does provide scope for the freehold sale of five general aviation airports including Jandakot. The others are Essendon, Moorabbin, Archerfield and Parafield and the regional airports of Mount Isa and Tennant Creek. Jandakot airport is in the area directly adjoining my electorate of Swan. It is known as one of the busiest airports in Australia. In fact, I am informed that it is the busiest airport in the Southern Hemisphere.

Under this bill, the Jandakot airport in Western Australia, as a general aviation airport, will be available on a freehold basis. This introduces some flexibility to the privatisation regime, as previously the sale of the airports was on a long‐term basis only. The opposition is opposing this aspect of the bill—the flexibility for some airports to be sold freehold and for the state law to apply to them. The member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) demonstrates the opposition's motives for this. They want the Commonwealth to retain the regulatory role that they currently play and do not want it shifted to the states.

The member for Melbourne also says that to do so would be detrimental to the aviation industry. I cannot see how shifting the regulatory role from the Commonwealth to the states automatically downgrades the safety and service, but the member for Melbourne seems to. He seems to think it would be ruinous to our aviation industry. This is a typical centralist sort of attitude which you would expect from the opposition. Why would an intrastate airport, with all the local benefits and local knowledge, be controlled from Canberra? It is ludicrous. You take away the ability of local authorities and local residents to have an input into the running and operation of something that affects them very directly.

From the example of many hundreds of local airports around the country, the freehold arrangements that would be in place for the Jandakot, Essendon and other airports would be on no different a footing from those that are already held under freehold title since they were transferred from the Commonwealth and subsequently had state law applied to their planning development. As an example, Merredin, the town I come from, has a state controlled airport. This airport has developed not only by transferring into this regime but also because Singaporean pilots now come there to do their training. We have plenty of free space in that part of the wheat belt.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not know you were a Merredin boy, Don?
—Didn't you?
—No.
—Well, I am. I went to Merredin high school.
—Order!
—They are reminiscing, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I do not need the help of the member for Fisher. The member for Swan will continue.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, there are very good reasons, regional ownership and state ownership having done good things, for airports to be held in freehold within the state and not controlled from Canberra. As I said, not only has the state controlled, Western Australian, airport in Merredin developed the airport but we have brought a significant industry to this airport by allowing the Singaporean air force to train there and not crowd the metropolitan skies.

BREAK.PARA: There are certain protections for residents and other interested parties in this bill, as there were in the Airports Act 1996, which provided for the sale of the major airports. This will ensure that the management of the airports, once privatised, continues in line with the standards in place when under government control. In other words, there is no diminution of standards or control. Because of these protections or regulations I am quite certain my constituents in Swan will not suffer nor be disadvantaged. It will, of course, ensure that the new owners of Jandakot airport will continue the same good neighbour policy that they have now and which the Perth airport currently practises. In fact, it will allow the residents to have a far greater input into the consultation phase of the master plan.

It is also with some interest that I note that the sale program of the former Federal Airports Corporation is reported to be the largest airport asset sale of its type in the world. I have not heard any criticism since 1 July—I know it is early days—but it seems to be all quite positive and we know it was supported by the opposition. It is with a lot of interest that I note the different style of negotiations set down by this government compared with those of the former government who were quite prepared to sell both Perth airport and Jandakot airport in a fire sale fashion and at a ridiculous price for the pair because they wanted to get rid of them.

I will give you a little insight. When I was the chairman of the planning committee on the Belmont City Council, we met with the then member for Swan, Mr Beazley, the mayor, and officers of the City of Belmont. Mr Beazley outlined his vision for the sale in a package deal involving Perth and Jandakot airports. I cannot forget his comment. Because Jandakot was a bit of a millstone as an airport, the only way to bail it out was to package it up with the Perth airport, throw several million dollars at it to allow the new buyer to find it attractive, and to be rid of it.

I have not got it here, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I am happy eventually to supply the council minute of that meeting just to show the attitude of the current member for Swan, Mr Beazley, towards getting rid of Jandakot. We know that there will be private buyers that are interested in buying Jandakot as a successful entity and, certainly, they will not be going into it to lose money. I also remember that some of the figures bandied around in that meeting of the Belmont City Council were far less than the $643 million that was gained for the Perth airport. So the sale so far has been quite judicious and responsible.

The opposition's amendments to this bill—and I did listen to the member for Melbourne when he spoke in the House yesterday—include a strengthening of the cross‐ownership policy. I am on the record as having supported—indeed, lobbied—the then Minister for Transport to ensure that the Perth airport would not be in a cross‐ownership deal with Sydney. It would have been very detrimental for the Perth airport to become an adjunct to the Sydney airport. Given our location on the western seaboard, and knowing the size and the strength of the Sydney airport operation I, like many others, feared that it would become a very poor relation if it were in the same ownership.

I stood for this and so did other colleagues of mine, including Senator Crane and Premier Richard Court. We lobbied very heavily. I remember, particularly, speaking to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), after question time one day. I know that it was an eleventh hour decision, but it was the right decision. I am very pleased to say that I did have an input into that and I am glad the government listened.

Thankfully, and due to this good approach, we do not have that cross‐ownership position in place now, though I see the member for Melbourne wants the cross‐ownership policy legislated and extended beyond a two‐year proposal. If this is the case, doesn't the member for Melbourne have any faith in the ACCC to regulate competition policy? This bill provides for a two‐year set down period and, after that, for business to operate in a responsible manner, regulated by the ACCC. I see no problems with that and I find it difficult to understand why the member for Melbourne does.

This government proposes to provide a zero cross‐ownership policy in relation to the airports in Brisbane and Coolangatta, Melbourne and Adelaide, Hobart and Launceston. As I said, this will be regulated after a two‐year period by the ACCC. This meets all of the regional expectations. What it does not do, as the opposition's proposal would, is to actually allow 15 per cent ownership of Coolangatta by Brisbane airport, and the same arrangement to apply between Hobart and Launceston. The current legislation limits cross‐ownership between Sydney and other major airports to 15 per cent, and this is what the opposition now intends to allow.

I also see that the member for Melbourne does not agree that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is superfluous to the consultative and decision making process. Efficient discussion and consultation mechanisms are already in place with management plans which invite extensive public consultation. This is seen in the sale of the Perth airport. There is a 90‐day consultation period and I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there are many interest groups who will involve themselves in this extensive consultation period. There are some strong lobby groups that will not allow the opportunity to pass them by. I am sure that this is the responsible approach to take, not to lay another level of bureaucracy, another level of hindrance, over the operation and sale of a public asset such as the further sale of the federal airports.

The opposition's attitude to the AAT reflects their complete lack of understanding of the act and the regulatory regime which applies to leased airports. Laying another level of bureaucracy over it would also allow it to be increasingly politicised and be a burdensome practice, and provide hurdles in the way of business in this country and of getting on with the job of doing business. I know that the current airport owners support the amendment to the bill which provides for a default approval by the minister of an airport management agreement, or a variation of an airport management agreement after 28 days. This is sensible and negates some of the unnecessary bureaucratic processes we have seen in the past which not only tie up ministers and departments, but the actual body seeking the approval. As you know, time is money when you are talking about business approval and business in general.

There are several aspects regarding the Jandakot airport that must be taken in context. Currently, because it is a federally owned airport, development has been allowed right to the fringes of the airport. There is a lot of pressure on the local residents. As I said, it is the busiest airport in the Southern Hemisphere, and even though they are light aircraft, in general, they cause a noise problem. I even had one of the councillors from the Leeming area tell me that his boy used to stand in the backyard trying to throw stones at the planes because they hated them so much. There certainly was no novelty seeing a Cessna fly over his house.

This has happened because there is this incongruous control of the airport—an airport federally controlled from Canberra. The state authorities did not even have the opportunity to put a notice on the title of these houses that were under flight paths. When it is owned, or on a long leasehold, if that is the case, in Western Australia, these sorts of things can be done. You can have far better controls over planning and planning approvals with the local authorities or in concert with the local authorities. It is with these things in mind that I say that with the privatisation—and I know that the opposition agrees with the privatisation because they were the people who began this process—the detail is that the states should control the domestic airports that have the light airport industry in their state and that the industry should be given the opportunity to get on with its business, not to go through a raft of what I believe are unnecessary amendments which will only hinder this process.

There is some move to see that Jandakot airport is moved out of the metropolitan area but, as we know, this bill does not agree with that. In fact, a section of this bill says that the sites continue as airports, that before any airport is sold freehold it will be ensured that the state and territory laws do not impede the continued airport operation and that the airport site will be restricted and will continue to be used as such.

I think any sensible person in Western Australia—and I know it applies to the other airports, but you will not mind my bias in speaking to this from a Western Australian perspective—will agree that there are problems which will continue to have to be sorted out in terms of airspace because of the busyness of the Jandakot airport and the proximity of the Pearce air base. However, I believe that these matters can be resolved far better at a local level in Western Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I wish this morning to speak on the Airports Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 and, like my Western Australian colleague the member for Swan (Mr Randall), I will focus on some Western Australian implications. The member for Swan and I normally have robust debates in the chamber of the House itself, Mr Deputy Speaker, but given the civilised decorum which I know you, more than most, encourage—indeed, insist on—in this chamber, I will be somewhat more judicious, civilised, circumspect and charitable in my comments today.

SPEECH.PARA: Mind you, I do see the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) on the speakers' list after me. I am not sure that he will be quite so charitable. But there are some important points which need to be made. The member for Swan has touched upon both Perth airport and Jandakot. I propose to touch upon Perth airport firstly because that is the major domestic and international airport in Western Australia and is an important economic asset to the state and, secondly, because in a local context, like the member for Swan, it affects my electorate. That is not the case so far as Jandakot is concerned.

The shadow minister for transport, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), has circulated a range of amendments which reflect the opposition's view of this bill and they will be returned to the House for consideration there in due course. The legislation itself refers to Perth airport. This is omnibus legislation which effects legislation by schedule. Items 4 and 9 of schedule number 1 list Perth airport as what is described as a core regulated airport and that reflects, as the minister said in his second reading speech, the status and the standing of those airports which were the phase 1 privatised airports.

But there is an important aspect in the legislation which goes to the regulation of those airports which this legislation seeks to change and which the opposition and I oppose. That goes to the question of the adoption by a privatised airport owner of a master or development plan. As the member for Swan outlined and most members who have airports in their areas would understand, following the privatisation of the airports, a new owner is required within 12 months to present a master plan or development plan, as described in the legislation, for approval by the minister. There is a consultation process that is required in the course of that exercise.

In the case of Perth, as the member for Swan well knows, the new owners, Airstralia Development Group, are required to present a development plan for Perth under the legislation by July of next year. Under the current legislation, that is approved or not approved by the minister after a process of consultation. But, under the legislation as it currently stands, the minister's decision in respect of that development plan is subject to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the AAT, by any affected resident or interested person.

It is that right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which this legislation seeks to remove. I argue and the opposition argues that this was a right given to potentially adversely affected residents surrounding an airport under the legislation which existed at the time privatisation occurred. It was in our legislation; it was in the member for Swan's government's legislation. What they now seek to do after privatisation of the airports is to remove that right at precisely that point in the cycle when the development plans will fall due for consideration. So you take out of the system something which potentially adversely affected residents and interested persons thought they had when the privatisation of the airports were undertaken. That can potentially have significant and adverse consequences for residents who live around Perth who may have an interest in the proposed development plan presented to the minister by the new airport owners.

What are some of the things which might fall due for consideration in that master plan? So far as Perth airport is concerned, there is a master plan that has been in place since the mid‐1980s and that master plan, as the member for Swan will appreciate, envisages a parallel runway in the fullness of time. Anyone who speaks to the owners or operators or people interested in the airport acknowledges that the introduction of a parallel runway at Perth airport, if it ever occurs, is not something likely to occur within the next 25 or 30 or 40 years.

There is a key point here which goes to the adoption of master plans and development plans around airports. Because the current master plan has been in place for about a decade, that is the basis on which long-term planning around the airport has proceeded. Perth airport is well served by interested local authorities who have formed the Perth Local Authorities Airport Group. These are the interested local authorities who determine, at the local level, the land use regime around the airport. They are the members of this local airport organisation.

The member for Swan would primarily be interested in the city of Belmont, which is a large part of his electorate. Other local authorities are in my electorate and they include the city of Bayswater, the town of Bassendean and the shire of Swan. The basis upon which these local authorities have proceeded for 10 years is the master plan which has been in place since the mid‐1980s. That is a very important aspect because if you now change the master plan, then 10 years of land use planning around the airport goes out the window.

What aspirations do people have for Perth airport? I believe that Perth airport is a very important economic asset to Western Australia by way of international trade and international tourism, but also internally for the state by way of the minerals and resources industry in the eastern goldfields and in the north‐west of Western Australia. For a large, geographically diverse state, economic growth, trade and jobs are what it is about.

At the same time you want to make sure that now or in the longer term Perth airport does not end up with the sorts of problems we now see at Sydney, and with sensible management you can achieve that. A bad management decision made now, a bad investment decision made now, or a bad planning decision made now, will have dire consequences in 10, 20 or 30 years time. That is the importance of making sure that whatever development or master plan is adopted now is a sensible one.

What is the most appropriate way of seeking to manage an urban airport, the state's important domestic and international airport, in a way in which you avoid the worst excesses of disruption to the local communities? There are a range of things which need to be taken into account and acted upon by way of policy measures. Who are those residents who are most adversely affected? In the case of Perth airport, from my geographical location, they are residents who live in South Guildford and Guildford. From the member for Swan's perspective they also include people who live in South Guildford as they are now redistributed into his electorate, but in terms of numbers they are more so at the southern part of his electorate in the city of Belmont.

I have argued for some time that what we ought to have in place in Perth is an extension of the noise compensation arrangements that apply to Sydney airport. There are people in Perth who live around Perth airport. Yes, they are far fewer in number but in a qualitative sense those people, particularly those who live in South Guildford, are as adversely affected by noise around Perth airport as some of the people in Sydney are affected by noise from Sydney airport.

The compensation regime which is in place for Sydney airport ought to be extended to Perth airport. That commitment was given by the previous Labor government. A noise audit contract was on the desk of the minister when the 1996 election was called, but it has not been proceeded with by this government. If you want to sensibly manage the airport you have to have a compensation program in place so that the most seriously adversely affected residents have some amelioration from noise.

Also, you have to get the land use planning right, which is why the local authorities around Perth airport have tried over time to be so diligent about these matters, and which is why you do not want to change the rules half way through.

I mentioned the proposed parallel runway in the master plan. What is also in the master plan at Perth airport is a reference to runway 0624, which is the north‐east, south‐west runway. Currently, the master plan envisages a modest extension of 0624 but there is one thing that aficionados are aware of which is an important point to make. Firstly, the noise contours, which are included in the master plan for Perth airport, are predicated on the basis that 0624 will not be used for take‐offs to the south‐west.

It is very important to the constituents of the member for Swan, and it is very important to my constituents. If take‐offs are allowed from runway 0624 to the south‐west, depending upon the prevailing breeze, if they turn to the north and to the west, suburbs such as East Perth, Mt Lawley, Maylands, Inglewood, Bedford, Bassendean, Beechboro, Morley and Embleton, which have never previously been substantially or at all affected by airport noise, will be dramatically affected by airport noise. So the noise contours in the master plan are predicated on the basis of no southerly take‐offs from runway 0624.

If you extend runway 0624 and you take off to the north and the west, then you need to be very careful about that because you can potentially adversely affect, in a way in which they are not currently affected, people who live in the suburb of Bellevue and people who live in the suburbs of Midland and Midvale. The planning that has occurred in respect of the shire of Swan, the relevant local authority, has been predicated on the basis of no extension to runway 0624 but on the parallel runway.

A further item, the configuration of Perth airport, is a suggestion recently that Perth be subject to a curfew. This was a suggestion made by Western Australian Democrat Senator Andrew Murray. Frankly, I was surprised that Senator Murray made this suggestion. When he made the suggestion, he was the Democrat spokesperson for small business and industry and he is now the Democrat spokesperson for treasury and economic matters.

The only consequence of a curfew at Perth airport would be to substantially and seriously impinge upon the economic viability of Perth airport and in many respects, in the long term, kill the economic viability of Perth airport. Perth airport is a staging ground for the international airline companies which come to Australia. If you have a curfew between 12 o'clock at night and 6 a.m., as Senator Murray suggested, you will destroy the long‐term economic viability of Perth airport. A curfew will mean a substantial diminution in international tourism, a substantial diminution in international trade, and a substantial diminution for Western Australia in economic growth, trade and jobs. It will have local adverse consequences as well because Western Australia's great minerals and resources industry utilises Perth airport in the early hours of the morning to send off either freight or personnel to minerals and resources projects in the north‐west of Western Australia and the eastern gold fields.

There is a technical problem in that a curfew between 12 and six does not prevent stacking, and very many of the early morning flights which currently arrive or go could be stacked between 11 p.m. and midnight and between 6 a.m. and 7 p.m. So you would have a process of concentrated activity just before midnight and just after 6 a.m. which, if there is an airport noise problem, does not actually address it properly. A curfew is a blunt instrument which will destroy the economic viability of Perth airport. Frankly, as I have said to the owners of Perth airport, it is just an excuse for poor management.

As I have said to the airport owners—and I have said it publicly—if the master plan or the development proposal for Perth airport contains a proposal to extend runway 0624, in a manner which is different from that which is currently in the master plan, then as sure as night follows day at some stage at Perth airport you will have a curfew because two things will have occurred. Firstly, the long‐term planning around the airport will have been put to one side and, secondly, the adverse consequences, so far as noise is concerned by utilising 0624 in a full capacity, will create such adverse consequences that policy makers will not be able to resist the application of a curfew over Perth airport. Perth airport needs to be properly and sensibly managed.

BREAK.PARA: There is a fifth item in the Perth airport management regime, and that is the configuration between the Pearce RAAF air base and Perth. The member for Swan referred to Jandakot and the potential difficulties which are caused between the configuration of Jandakot to the south and west and Perth airport, but much more difficult is the configuration of Pearce air base and Perth airport.

If you speak to air traffic controllers and Airservices Australia personnel who have to manage the flight paths, what they say to you anecdotally is that you could not have picked a worse configuration. If you were starting again with an empty UBD of Perth and you wanted to come up with the worst configuration of three airports—a general aviation airport like Jandakot, an international stage 1 main phase airport like Perth and a RAAF base like Pearce—from an air traffic controller's point of view you could not have picked a worse configuration.

The most sensible thing that can be done for the long‐term sustainability of Perth airport is to get on top of, and control, the planning that occurs between Perth airport and the RAAF base. But what has occurred with the RAAF base over preceding years? The planning for the Pearce RAAF base has been done wholly in isolation. It has been done wholly in isolation by the RAAF, by the Department of Defence, with absolutely no heed to that which occurs at Perth airport.

The time has come to bring the planning of the Pearce RAAF base and Perth airport into a wholly and fully coordinated regime. The utilisation of some of the current Pearce RAAF base by Perth airport for arrivals and departures is one of the most significant things that could be done to substantially diminish, ameliorate and minimise airport noise, particular for those people who live to the north and east of the airport.

The most significant thing that airport planners and policy makers can do in the short to medium term is to bring the planning of the Pearce RAAF base and Perth airport into a coordinated regime. That is the most effective thing that can be done to do two things: to ensure the long‐term viability of Perth airport and to ensure that airport noise is minimised so far as residents are concerned.

Now, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will come back to that part of the legislation which has serious deleterious consequences for my constituents and the people who live around Perth airport. This bill proposes to remove from the legislation the capacity for interested persons to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against the decision of the minister to adopt, in whole or in part, a development plan for Perth airport or any other airport mentioned in the schedules of the airports legislation. That is a right which existed when the airports were privatised. It was a right which existed when the former government, the Labor government, announced that the airports would be privatised. It was a right which existed when the member for Swan voted for the privatisation of the airports. It is now proposed to take it away, at precisely that point in the cycle when it is most relevant.

The future for Perth airport is to link Perth to the planning regime adopted around the airport to minimise adverse consequence for residents and to maximise the economic importance of the airport to the state. Continue the long‐term land use planning by the local authorities around the airport, and continue the current master plan which has been in operation since the mid‐eighties for a long‐term parallel runway but with no extension of 0624. Continue to argue forcefully in the community that a curfew over Perth airport is a blunt instrument which does not properly address the problems but which will kill the economic viability of Perth airport. Fourthly, and most importantly, bring the current, uncoordinated planning for the Pearce RAAF base under control and have that properly and centrally coordinated by one regime to ensure the long‐term viability of Perth airport.

For those reasons, Mr Deputy Speaker, when this bill returns to the House for the detailed committee stage I will be strongly supporting the amendments outlined by the shadow minister for transport, the member for Melbourne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey, Wilson, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of issues arising from the simple amendments proposed in the Airports Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 , and also opportunities to comment on air transport and the operation of airports, but I wish to take the opportunity before the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) leaves to point out that, of course, the proposal of the government is consistent with all ministerial decisions when it comes to the removal of a reference or the ability to appeal to the AAT. Ministerial decisions can be subject to scrutiny by way of the rules of the House and become disallowable instruments tabled in the parliament, where the very people that the community elects have an opportunity in either house to review them by disallowing them; or, of course, we have the judicial review legislation which allows for public appeal and the use of the courts.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Stephen Smith interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No. The proposal that our party room was advised of is that the change will be from AAT to disallowable instrument. The minister, we are told, will table the determination in the House and, of course, it follows that it is a disallowable instrument. The advantage of that process is that it gives to one house of the parliament—for instance, the Senate—the opportunity to override that decision on behalf of the constituency they believe they represent. The realities are that it gives the House of Representatives the opportunity to do it also, where of course the opposition of the day is never very well represented. But the realities are that that opportunity exists.

SPEECH.PARA: Just this morning we had queues of people around the place demanding the continuation of legislation in the Aboriginal area, legislation that opens up thousands of opportunities for litigation. We have $80 million of Aboriginal money that should have been spent on people's health going to lawyers. The same situation applies here. If the parliament can deal with it, why should we leave it to the courts?

It has been a trend, which I criticise substantially, of this parliament even to admit with new legislation that they are bringing in a law but they are not really sure what it means but that, no doubt, at some time in the future the courts will tell us. Of course, in the interim, the community walks around not knowing whether it is breaking the law or not. If large amounts of money are involved, as could be so in this case, that is an unsatisfactory situation. All parties are entitled to see these matters cleared up. The fact is that there is still a substantial opportunity for review of the ministerial decision. It is one of the two choices available on this. In fact, it is generally believed that disallowable instrument is the better response, because it is certainly not—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the rationale for taking it away?

—The rationale is efficiency in making it a determination of the parliament, the law‐makers of this country—as compared to some unelected judge who sits out there being addressed by lawyers who, in the state of Western Australia, as you would be aware, now charge $25 for every six minutes. That is a huge cost to both sides, a cost which is frequently never recovered. But I do not want to go on with that debate.

BREAK.PARA: I make the point that the suggestion is that there is no review in the future, but that is wrong. The review will be done in that very appropriate place, the parliament. It is similar of course to the opposition to the freeholding of some of these places. As the member for Swan (Mr Randall) knows very well, prior to the privatisation proposal the FAC was proposing a major commercial development at Perth airport. Personally, I thought it may have had some advantages, but it was going to be extremely disadvantageous to other people who, under the planning provisions of the state government of Western Australia, had invested large amounts of money—thinking they understood that no other competition was available. Here we have two jurisdictions working side by side whereas, as the member for Swan has already pointed out, once these properties are freeholded they are subject to state law—although we make it very clear that such freeholding will not occur until there are adequate arrangements in place with state, and state planning, authorities relative to the continued existence of the airport.

The matter that has been discussed by the last two speakers was Jandakot airport. I was once the holder of a private pilot's licence. I can remember flying down from Carnarvon to Jandakot airport. My overview as we came into land was literally miles of undeveloped bush surrounding this airport. It required almost a map and a water bag to find your way into the city of Perth.

Did the planners try and keep that exclusivity? No, everyone wanted to build a house out there. I am astounded that, be it Sydney airport, Perth airport or Jandakot airport, people can complain about the noise when not one of them owned the house before the airport was built there. They all knew what it was about.

Do not tell me that old DC3s were not noisy. I lived next to the Carnarvon airport and I can tell you that, when they got out of the airport, they were still only 150 feet off the ground and the houses used to shake. That was compared to modern jet aircraft, notwithstanding their frequency. That is the matter I want to really address today. The realities are that more and more aircraft are getting quieter and quieter.

I have some rights to make those remarks. I can drive from my house to the Perth airport domestic terminal in 2½ minutes. It cannot be said of me that I live in some exclusive area miles away from the airport. I live right at the end of one runway. Admittedly, it is not the one that is used most frequently. I know a bit about airports. I find that these people want to destroy the economic arrangements.

Perth is extremely fortunate to have an airport so conveniently located. It makes it a great attraction to people visiting our city. The member for Perth mentioned the long‐term potential for a parallel runway. I was one of those that petitioned the then minister, Wal Fife—another was Peter Shack, whose electorate was significantly affected—to get the new international airport, which was commenced under the Fraser government and opened by then Prime Minister Hawke, put on the other side of the main runway, so when the second parallel runway is in place the terminals will be between it. It was hoped by many of the local authorities that in time the domestic terminal would shift to there to encourage the construction of the second runway. Geographically that would have been a better situation.

There has been quite a lot of planning of Perth airport, because Perth airport does have rural land on the typical approaches and industrial land at the end of the typical departure course. It is pretty well done. It is ridiculous for people to be so silly as to suggest that there should be curfews at that airport, or at Jandakot airport, when each and every house that is being affected today was built long after its construction.

It is interesting that the minister's second reading speech also mentions some of the issues relating to Sydney airport and particularly how things will be delayed until final decisions are taken about a second major airport for Sydney, such as that proposed at Badgerys Creek. When you have certain responsibilities in this place, you try and expand your knowledge.

Over a long time since it was first mooted, the idea of a very fast train between Melbourne and Sydney has been something that I believe has great economic and environmental potential. More recently, I wondered if we have ever sat down and done a proper survey of our transport infrastructure—roads, airports and high‐speed rail—as it shifts passengers. What is the opportunity for one to reduce the demand on another?

Whilst I cannot put any figures to this House, I have a gut feeling that if an appropriate high‐speed rail, as is now being considered for Sydney‐Canberra, was extended to Melbourne, you might not have to build Badgerys Creek airport at all. With that linkage—and the interconnection and the load sharing you could achieve between Melbourne, Canberra and Sydney—you might already have sufficient airport infrastructure. You would have an adequate connection. I am talking about the only suitable speed at which that is achievable and that is somewhere around 450 to 500 kilometres an hour. Fortunately, that technology is now available. I have ridden in it. It is the magnetic—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have done 421 kilometres an hour in a train. That is the point I make. Three hundred is about the end of your wheeled technology, once you go into magnetic levitation. I have been in the vehicle—it is available. I have been on a test track. I have done 421 kilometres an hour in that vehicle, and that was on a 20‐kilometre track. The main constraint on its speed was getting up and getting down again from those speeds.

BREAK.PARA: The realities are that we can have a train service running on a form of monorail, which removes a lot of the disadvantages of resumption of land and some of the other environmental opportunities, operating between Melbourne and Sydney, via Canberra and places like Wollongong and Goulburn. You can have that running at 500 kilometres an hour on existing technology. That is 40 or 50 minutes from Canberra to Sydney, and about two hours from Sydney to Melbourne.

Once you have done that, the demands on the existing airports, with the reduction—I do not say the annihilation—of domestic travel, both interstate and intrastate, is the first improvement you get in terms of greater opportunities to compensate international arrivals. The second is that you start to share the international arrivals. Perth is a gateway for traffic from the west and, to a degree, from the north. Melbourne is equally advantageous in that regard, if people could step out of their plane and get onto an extremely comfortable train that would have them in Sydney—if that was their destination—in two hours.

These are arguments; they are not facts. But I am hopeful, and I have made representations to the newly appointed Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile) that we should really and truly start to consider this. That sort of high‐speed rail has a freight capacity. It is not a heavy freight capacity, but the sort of items to a great degree that are travelling up and down the Hume Highway, with thousands of trucks every night, could be also on that rail service.

A lot of it would travel in the daytime in separate carriages simply because it would be able to be combined with passenger travel. I understand that the carriages could carry about 80 tonnes of freight, which is quite a lot. The idea of getting a lot of that traffic off the Hume Highway would be very attractive to many people in the environmental sense and also, of course, in terms of the maintenance cost of many of those roadways.

If we are prepared—it just might be something where we look to a bit of bipartisan interest—we should be sitting down with a joint standing committee of the parliament. I think my particular committee, the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Public Works, would be an ideal body to do just that, and say, `How do we interlink road infrastructure, airport infrastructure, and fast rail infrastructure in this highly populated, relatively wealthy south‐eastern part of Australia to maximise the benefit of both, and reduce particularly the environmental problems that arise today from airports?'

Whilst I have put points about existing airports and the complaints that people have about them, I cannot put those arguments on the case of a new airport. Quite obviously, the people that live anywhere near where one of them will be built have got a lot of reasons for complaint. It just might be that we have a better option. What is more—I am sure it would not be long if that happened—we would see a similar transport system starting to run north of Sydney, where you have a couple of very substantial military airports—Richmond is one, and I think the other is Waverley. Is it Waverley?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Williamtown.

—Yes, Williamtown. That is where it is—near Newcastle. There are things called spur lines. But the reality is that you have another big block of international‐style runways—if not facilities—that again, if that infrastructure went north, over time, would put Newcastle 20 minutes—or something—out of Sydney and, of course, the linkage with those airports.

BREAK.PARA: This is a very responsible position that this House should be taking. We have tended to see them in packages: roads is roads; aeroplanes is aeroplanes; and trains—we have not got any of them.

I want to come back to this maglev technology; I have been on the wheeled TGV, too. I take a significant interest in this. Because the power required to move them is on the rails, there is a point at about 300 kilometres an hour when the cost benefits cease and the amount of power you have got to put on the rails actually starts to work against itself. When you go to maglev technology, the power is in the track. You actually have a stator in the track. You can therefore climb a 10-degree grade because when you get to that section of the track, with the same carriage, which carries no motors, you just increase the power of that section of the track. It is an interesting thing. Technically, at least, you also cannot have a collision because, if two trains are on the same section of track, they can only travel in the same direction because the power is in the track.

It is long‐established technology that has been perfected in recent times, no doubt because of the availability of computerisation. The Germans have got one working. The Japanese are not far behind them. They will parallel the bullet train with this type of technology.

Why do you need 500 kilometres per hour? Because the greater the distance, the more competitive in time is an aeroplane. If you have not got those levels of speeds between Melbourne and Sydney, you will not get the passengers. Somebody is suggesting that we should have a tilt train between Canberra and Sydney which, I am advised, would take half an hour less than it would take to drive to Canberra once the road upgrade is completed. That is a recipe for a disaster. Of course, it would never compete with an aeroplane, where probably, central city to central city, you are looking at about an hour. You have got to get that central city to central city time to about the same.

With all the debates we have over airports and the problems they genuinely create for people, I am asking the parliament to think about getting down to the idea of looking at the three together. I would love to think it was viable for my city of Perth, but the population is not there.When one addresses the financial viability of this proposal, one just has to think of the great sporting events that occur every weekend between Melbourne and Sydney today, with AFL competition and so on, and of how many people would move back and forward if they could do the trip in two hours in groups of 1,000. That is the sort of situation that we are confronted with.

In my mind, it is also the sort of project that we want, to address unemployment and to give the Australian people a bit of confidence that this country has still got a future and can get into this sort of Snowy River project of today. The actual structure is such that it could be a huge help to the steel industry directly. In fact, from the type of structures that are used, it would also employ a lot of unemployed people. The roadway is quite basic structural technology. I have had a look at it; I have taken photographs of it.

I ask the House to give some consideration to that. I think it is something we should all support. I have had a conversation with the minister and I am sure he understands the logic of my argument. There are many factors to apply and, quite clearly, the research needs to be done to support my arguments. I think it would be a great idea and it could be a huge attraction, even to tourism, with people travelling between those airports.

If we were to put in Badgerys Creek at a cost of $3 billion and then put another few billion into all the connecting infrastructure—albeit fuel pipes or the suburban type of electric trains—it would be further away in time than Canberra from Sydney. On an ordinary suburban train, it would be further away in time than on a maglev train.

TALK.START.PARA: —You think Wollongong is on the way to Canberra.
—I can tell you that the proposed route goes through Wollongong. So that shows how much you know about what is happening in your own state. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendments moved by the shadow minister for transport, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner). If those amendments are not successful, the opposition has indicated through the shadow minister that we will be opposing the Airports Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 .

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition has moved amendments which would remove the aspect of this bill which would enable the freehold sale of the airports. We are also moving amendments to remove the amendments that take ministerial decisions outside the scope of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. We are also concerned about the removal of the existing cross‐ownership rules relating to Adelaide and Melbourne, Hobart and Launceston, and Coolangatta and Brisbane, along with the cross‐ownership rules preventing Townsville being owned with Brisbane, and Townsville being owned with Cairns.

The previous Labor government, in privatising the airports, was keen to ensure that there were very strong cross‐ownership provisions to ensure that major airports were not owned by the same operators, and, with regard to the smaller airports, particularly, that local ownership of those airports was encouraged. That has certainly occurred with local government in a number of areas bidding successfully for the ownership of those airports.

BREAK.PARA: With regard to the freehold ownership provision, I think that it certainly should be opposed. One of the concerns that many residents around airports had with the privatisation of the airports was the issue of government regulation. The freehold ownership of the airports would, indeed, in conjunction with this legislation, shift some of the planning control for those airports to state governments. The state governments have indicated that they do not particularly want control over the planning of these airports. Indeed, this bill should be seen as a package, to represent a dilution of regulation of these airports and of the ability of residents around the airports to have an influence on, and a say in, these important issues.

I particularly want to concentrate today on my concern about the removal of the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of ministerial decisions. This would apply in a number of areas: to master plans, to environmental plans, and to flight paths. All of those decisions would be removed so that the only right of appeal which residents would have would be to the Federal Court. The Federal Court would be very expensive, and prohibitive for the average resident. In an electorate such as mine, the average resident or, indeed, any residents' groups and community associations simply could not afford to appeal to the court.

It is symptomatic of my concern that the Marrickville council took action against the federal Labor government of the time on behalf of the community to oppose the expansion of facilities at Sydney airport. That was a court action which I supported as a resident and as a local representative. The current government—the then opposition—thought that court action was a terrific idea, as well, and encouraged the local council to represent the community's interests. But when Marrickville council lost that particular case, we saw the federal government pursue Marrickville council for the federal government's share of the court costs. It should be acknowledged that Marrickville council quite correctly represented and advanced the views of the community. Under the leadership of Mayor Barry Cotter, they had a responsibility to represent residents' interests.

What we have here is incredible hypocrisy. Before the election we saw John Howard, as the member for Bennelong and not just as the leader of the then opposition, and other members, such as the member for Lowe, Paul Zammit, who was then the candidate for Lowe, purport to be concerned about Sydney airport. Now, the government is doing nothing other than punishing the residents of Marrickville for taking action. It is the ratepayers, the people who have been subjected to an inordinate level of aircraft noise, more so than any other community in this nation, who are forced to pay the costs. It will not come out of the mayor's salary. It will not come out of the deputy mayor's salary. It will mean a further cutback in facilities.

We had a meeting with the previous minister for transport, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp) about a week before his resignation as the minister. He indicated that he was unsympathetic to our cause. I hope to make representations to the incoming Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), and I congratulate him on his elevation to the cabinet. We will be making representations to ensure that the people of Marrickville are not punished for their council's decision to stand up for their community.

I think that highlights the reason why the Administrative Appeals Tribunal appeal needs to be maintained, because what we see at Sydney airport, on every front almost, are issues about which residents are concerned. Firstly, we see the ongoing expansion of facilities at Sydney airport. The previous speaker, the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), raised the issue of the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works. The public works committee of this parliament on 19 June 1997 approved the upgrading of the international terminal at Kingsford Smith airport, to the tune of $350 million. The Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) announced on the 29 August 1997 that an EIS for this massive expansion of facilities was not required.
