It seems that we need great details and, indeed, decades of EISs into a second Sydney airport, which of course was first raised by the Chifley government and has been raised ever since by governments but we have seen very little action. But when it comes to a $350 million expansion at Sydney airport, that can just be approved with the tick of a pen by the minister. They are the sorts of decisions which create a great deal of alarm for residents around Sydney airport because, whilst we hear a lot of rhetoric about action, about flight paths and second airports, all that residents see—and, indeed, all that commuters see every time they go to Sydney airport—are ever expanding facilities. There are roads being dug up, terminals being expanded, car parks being built and the rail network being built there.

Indeed, it is a frightening revelation that there are supporters in the cabinet of a fourth runway for Sydney airport—a fourth runway which would be parallel to the current east‐west runway, built into the bay, which would allow for up to 150 movements per hour at Sydney airport. That has supporters not only in the cabinet—the Treasurer (Mr Costello), I understand—but also has considerable support, of course, from the airline industry and the FAC, who have opposed any real solution to Sydney airport's difficulties at every possible opportunity. So the removal of these expansion plans from public scrutiny is a retrograde aspect of this bill and something which the opposition is certainly trying to amend today.

I am a member of the Sydney Airport Community Forum and this bill refers to master plans. When we had the first meeting of the Sydney Airport Community Forum, we asked the then head of the FAC at Sydney airport, `What is the master plan? Is there a five‐year plan or a 10‐year plan at Kingsford Smith?' We were told that we were not in a position to be advised. We were only the minister's appointed body to represent the community. But we could not be told whether there was a five‐year plan or a 10‐plan at Sydney airport. We were deliberately held back from information such as the FAC's involvement in a plan at Rockdale to build a Darling Harbour type development as part of the expansion at Sydney airport. It is that sort of deception which we have seen from the bureaucrats and the industry which causes great concern for the people that I represent.

With regard to flight paths at Sydney airport, we are going to see the long‐term operating plan introduced on 4 December. That plan, whilst having some good elements, also has some disastrous elements, the biggest disaster being that there will actually be a decrease of take‐offs over water under that plan, contrary to the government's commitments prior to the election. There will be an increase in take‐offs over the north‐west of my electorate. That is for one reason and for one reason only: the plan favours the North Shore. There has been one thing constant about Sydney airport and that is that, whoever has been in government, there has always been a bias towards landings from the north rather than take‐offs to the north for the simple reason that that is where the residents are and take‐offs are a lot noisier than landings. But now we have a proposition that we will restrict the landings from the north because the landings have to come in over a straight line and affect the residents of Bennelong and others on the North Shore of Sydney. We will forget about that and have a preference for take‐offs to the north which will then spray in four different arcs over the western parts of my electorate, in particular the Ashfield municipality, and all over the electorate of Lowe, contrary to the commitments in Putting people first, the Liberal policy launched by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in the electorate of Lowe, in which he stated that there would be no new flight paths over that part of Sydney. I think that the removal of the right of appeal is something which is indeed a very negative step.

I think also that residents should have access to appeal over specific problems with the airport. We saw a 747 having to turn back when they had problems with one of their engines just one month ago over Petersham in my electorate. We are talking about the most densely populated area of Australia, not just Sydney. We have seen, and I have drawn to this parliament's attention, the repeated breaches of the fuel dumping provisions over the residents in my electorate. That is something which caused great concern. Due to questions which I asked of the minister, we discovered that, in events on 30 July 1996, 13 August 1996, 15 October 1996 and 14 January 1997, one airline alone, Evergreen Airlines, sprayed fuel all over my electorate and the electorate of Lowe. All of these aircraft were Boeing 747‐200s. These planes have a capacity to vent approximately 379 litres of fuel—189.5 litres in each wing—all over people's houses, their cars, schools, parks and child‐care centres throughout my electorate. When that occurs, what you need is some government accountability. It took me months to get answers to the questions on notice which I placed in response to residents ringing up my office and putting in complaints about this.

On a range of issues, whether it be the big picture, whether you start with expansion of an airport, whether you look at the flight paths, or whether you look at the specific operations of planes operating from an airport, be it Sydney or any other airport in Australia, you do need provisions which allow residents to have proper scrutiny of ministerial decisions in relation to the operation of those airports. I am greatly concerned that this legislation is very much a retrograde step with regard to that scrutiny.

I will conclude by saying I am a strong supporter of a second Sydney airport to be built at Badgerys Creek in western Sydney. However, I will support that airport only after a proper environmental impact statement has been done because I am not about simply transferring the problem of noise in my electorate to the electorate of anyone else. I do not want anyone to suffer as the people of Sydenham and St Peters have suffered.

The way to do that is to have proper planning for that second airport. There must be a properly integrated public transport system because the greatest threat to air quality in the Sydney basin will not be from the planes at western Sydney; it will be from the cars taking people to and from that airport. If you have a look at the problems in my electorate, they certainly are not due just to the planes; they are due to the whole environmental impact arising from an airport in the centre of Sydney. You need proper planning at Sydney West airport. You also need to ensure that people will have proper scrutiny provisions available so the disaster that is Kingsford Smith airport is not repeated.
I commend to the House the amendments which the opposition has moved today and suggest that if those amendments are not carried then this bill should be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity to speak in this debate on the Airports Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 . I will start by saying that I subscribe to a magazine called Airline Business , one of the bibles of commercial aviation around the world. In this month's edition, October 1997, there is an excellent article that is concentrating its focus on the future of Sydney airport.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese), who has just spoken, and any other members who may be interested in this area, should get a copy of this article. It also gives an overview into the privatisation of Australia's airports and an overview of what is happening already in terms of the privatised airports in Brisbane and Melbourne. It describes how the transfer of those airports into private ownership is already rejuvenating the aviation industry in Australia and how it may help the industry reach its full potential as one of the most potent forces in aviation in South‐East Asia.

What we are discussing today is really stage 2 of that privatisation process, which is one of the biggest airport privatisations ever undertaken in the world. This particular move by this government really has some exciting prospects for new industry, as that article says, and for the realisation of the full effect of Australian aviation in terms of the future development of South‐East Asia.

Of course, privatisation does give some tremendous prospects in terms of local communities and, at last, the freeing of government instrumentalities from the shackles that have inhibited the operation and future expansion of a number of those airports, whether they be capital city airports, regional airports, or some of the local airports that are up for sale.

One of the things that has upset me in the past hour or two, listening to members of the opposition in their presentations today, is simply that they do not seem to have learned very much. I say that because what they are trying to do with these particular amendments that have been proposed is stifle what could at last be a tremendous expansion of new business for aviation in Australia.

I will concentrate very briefly on a couple of points. The reality is that the government foresaw what would happen if those cross‐ownership provisions were not in place in this particular legislation. There could be no greater example of what an absolute disaster the lack of cross‐ownership provisions is than would exist if the ownership of Brisbane and Coolangatta were to fall into the same hands. Frankly, I was delighted to see that the Schiphol consortium got ownership of Brisbane airport because Schiphol is one of the most competitive airports in the world.

We can see already that the BAA part ownership of Melbourne airport has put competitive forces in there as well. I do not think that there would be much future for Coolangatta airport if the BAA consortium owned both instrumentalities. In fact, it would be a very good proposition to close down Coolangatta, particularly to international traffic, and divert it all through that principal gateway. Apart from that, the other thing that should be considered is the sort of return that we are going to get from these airports if we do not have those provisions on cross‐ownership.

For six years, I shadowed aviation in opposition. In fact, I did a great deal of work on the privatisation of airports. I have been convinced for some 15 years that it was the way to go but that the one thing that we had to make absolutely sure of was simply the fact that we did not create a private monopoly, and this legislation is going to be such that it will prevent that private monopoly. A number of things came out in all of that work that we did over the years on airport privatisation, but one thing that always impressed me was that Coolangatta airport was probably one of the best investments of the whole lot of the airports that were to be offered for sale.

The potential of Coolangatta, a small airport, admittedly, is enormous. But its real potential is in limited international flights. Already we have seen what can be achieved by allowing limited international flights into Coolangatta. The advent of Freedom Air and the predecessor from New Zealand is probably a typical example of that. There has been an increase in the figures for New Zealanders holidaying on the Gold Coast over the last couple of years. The principal reasons for that increase are that we have had that competition and that limited charter operations have been allowed to go in there. The Gold Coast infrastructure has benefited very greatly from the advent of those flights.

As I say, the real difficulty is if you allow a situation to exist where there is ownership or even part ownership, which is really what the effect of the opposition's amendments will be. Under the opposition's amendments, the Brisbane airport consortium could own about 15 per cent of Coolangatta. As you would well know, Mr Deputy Speaker, 15 per cent of the ownership is a pretty influential slice to have and you could in fact see a lot of that competition going.

I think the same could certainly be said if there was similar ownership between Melbourne and Adelaide. Adelaide has always struggled to establish itself as an international gateway and that is fully understandable. But, with the prospect of being in private hands and the right to go out and to compete, there are some opportunities for Adelaide to get some of that limited international traffic, particularly in the charter area.

I emphasise the point that the whole thing about this exercise is competition. The one thing that causes me some concern is that while we are going to have these airports open to competition, and while we should have good viable operators being able to go out there and to get the business, the government has to make absolutely certain that the regulatory authorities in Australia allow some of that competition to happen. And, frankly, I do not think our record in this country has been terribly good over the last 15 years.

We have mouthed all sorts of platitudes about opening up to competition, and the reality is that we have made some progress. Limited charter operators are now allowed into Australia. But, day after day, you hear stories of what has been happening in the International Air Services Commission, the attitudes of the established carriers in Australia. If anybody thinks that there is an open slather market, think again. We have seen real evidence of some of the approaches that have been made by the established international operators over the last couple of years to make sure that their market is maintained as a cosy area.

I was absolutely surprised to read in the Financial Review on Monday that the IASC had rejected a Qantas application for code sharing rights with British Airways on some of the sectors between Australia and Europe. I really wonder what the authorities are trying to achieve. The whole of the international aviation industry is moving towards these consortia. Qantas is in there with British Airways and American, which is potentially the second biggest consortium. They are going in with Iberia of Spain and I think it is VASP of Brazil to try to give themselves some coverage. On top of that, what is known as the Star Alliance is anchored on carriers like Lufthansa, Singapore Airways and Thai International. I think Delta is in there, too, and that is the world's biggest conglomerate. What are we doing? We are doing our best to make sure that Qantas may not have the full capacity to be able to get in there and share some of this international traffic through this code sharing process.

The reality is that what is happening in international aviation, and what will continue to happen in international aviation, is that carriers will no longer be national carriers of a particular state in the true sense, but they will be part of blocs. There will be blocs of nations which have banded together and which will be cross‐selling and cross‐utilising their equipment to get the most efficient use out of it—and, indeed, in terms of passenger traffic, to be able to get some real fare benefits out of the arrangements as well.

BREAK.PARA: I think that the move that was made by the IASC, even though it was said to be in the best national interest, is probably not going to work that way at all. If Australia is going to play a part in global international operations, we have got to review our thinking there.

On top of that, we have to be as liberal as we possibly can in terms of this limited charter traffic that is coming around, particularly from the region of South‐East Asia. We have to make sure that some of these secondary airports, whether they be capital city or regional airports, have full and open access for those new operators to get in and to provide the traffic in and out.

There is some real evidence at the moment that, while we have in the past traditionally relied on carriers from New Zealand and to a degree from the UK, we are now starting to see the opening up of regional charter traffic from some of the Asian countries. I understand that, to their credit, the IASC has just granted rights to a new Japanese charter carrier which is a division of Japan Air Services, the third carrier in Japan, to start operating some limited charter flights into Brisbane. That has got to be welcomed.

The other thing this does, particularly in terms of local ownership, is to give future owners of these airports an opportunity to open up some new industries. Airports are no longer just places where planes land. An airport has become an integrated area that has the capacity to promote great industry, to bring new industries into areas and to revitalise areas.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I know you would have a great interest in Alice Springs airport. I think Alice Springs airport has tremendous potential, though not necessarily as a major hub for the arriving and taking off of airline passengers. The physical area of Alice Springs airport is the largest in Australia. If we look at some of the developments that have happened overseas, particularly in the United States, we see that some of the things that can be done in desert conditions in terms of aviation are absolutely enormous, because the environmental conditions there are right.

Some years ago I went to Mojave, which is in the Mojave Desert about 160 miles outside Los Angeles. Mojave is one of the largest aircraft storage and maintenance bases in the world. At that stage, which was at the time of the downturn of international aviation, there were no fewer than 1,000 passenger aircraft parked in Mojave.

The reasons they were parked were numerous. There had been a number of carriers in the United States that had gone out of business, and the aircraft were parked there for future sales. There were direct deliveries from some of the major manufacturers of brand new aircraft, who parked them in the desert until business picked up enough to allow them to go. Allied to this, of course, there developed a whole new aircraft maintenance division. Part of it was for the maintenance of these stored aircraft; part of it was for the destruction of the old aircraft and getting parts together as they melted down some of these aeroplanes. It was really an incredible operation.

The town of Mojave was really like the back of Bourke. There was very little there. It was a tiny settlement. But, out of the move to establish the desert aviation park, a whole new town emerged. The thing about it was that the people who were employed were pretty technically skilled and consequently their incomes were fairly high and, from the midst of nowhere, there developed a tremendous little town that really did make a contribution to the surrounding districts. Because of the fact that one of the US air force's major bases is about 50 or 60 miles away from it, the town also managed to feed off some of the work of that.

If you look at a place like Alice Springs and if you look around South‐East Asia, you see that there are very few areas where this facility is available. Australia, I think, does have the capability of doing that. Looking around South‐East Asia now, you see where some of the excess airliners are parked: some are in the jungles of Thailand, which would hardly be conducive to the maintenance of airframes, and others are parked at various airports in the middle of nowhere. We could have the new owners of Alice Springs airport, for example, look at this particular concept, as there is a possibility of bringing in a whole new industry there. Whether it be at Alice Springs, Jandakot, or Archerfield in Brisbane, there is the capacity to be able to create whole new industries.

In fact, as I said, airports are not just about passengers coming and going. They can be about allied industries and about general industry. One of the things that you will probably see with some of these facilities is that there will be a great deal of general industry generated by the new owners to maximise absolutely the usage of these airport areas. The flow‐on effect of that into local communities is going to be great.

The opposition are also moving amendments in terms of the control of airports. They have stated that they have some opposition and that state governments are not particularly keen on taking over the supervision of some of these newly privatised airports. I can understand that, because the history of local government and state government in airport administration and airport development has been absolutely appalling.

It was interesting to hear the member for Grayndler make mention of Badgerys Creek and the need for EISs. Badgerys Creek in the mid‐1980s was a greenfields site. I have had meetings with WESROC and various council members—a couple of them prominent members who have since served in the House here—about what they wanted to see for Badgerys Creek, and the potential for Badgerys Creek was enormous. In the construction phase, it would have been about 5,500 jobs. When the airport was finished, it would have been initially about 9,500 jobs for the local residents, as the spin‐off from all those new industries. And what have we seen? We have seen development approvals for housing estates all over the place. I personally would have some doubts now as to whether you would ever get a Badgerys Creek through an EIS.

That is really one of the great problems that we have had: there has been total and absolute irresponsibility by some of our local authorities and state governments in the way they have regarded this airport development. One of the classic cases is the case of Essendon airport. We have heard the bleatings from governments of Victoria about selling Essendon airport off for more housing estates. Here you have one of the greatest facilities just sitting there. If you get rid of Essendon, where are you going to put a second airport for Melbourne? I guess it is going to be out Cranbourne way. They have already written off Point Cook as a prospective site.

When you look at what Essendon provides for that local community, there are maintenance shops and heavy engineering shops around there. To take that out of circulation would be absolutely irresponsible. You have that facility there; it is well‐established. I think that, with the right ownership and the right management, the potential of Essendon airport to expand and get back to some of its former glory is going to be a very real prospect indeed.

I have spoken longer than I intended to. I do get a bit excited about this legislation because I think that we now really have the capacity to be able to get into the world league in terms of the development of our airports and of new high‐tech aviation facilities in Australia. It has the potential not only to create a great deal of export income for us, but also flow‐on in some real benefits to the people of Australia.

I commend the bill to the House. I would totally reject the proposed amendments from the opposition. I would sincerely hope that the opposition members would start rethinking some of their attitudes towards the aviation industry because the effect of their amendments would be to stifle the potential for very real gains for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marek, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Many would be well aware I am the owner and operator of my own twin‐engined Cessna 310 aircraft. I have owned it for approximately seven years. Therefore, I guess it is somewhat fitting I talk on aviation issues. It is also with great pleasure that I accept the new position on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform.

SPEECH.PARA: The Airports Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 is the second phase in the sale of federal airports. The flexibility is allowing some of the remaining airports to be sold on a freehold basis. On the outset, one could become concerned about the fact that governments continue to sell off assets and I am compassionate about a lot of those people's concerns. But people must understand various reforms are necessary to kick‐start the country and to change the mentality from where people believe that this country and the government owe them something. This is wrong. It is this socialist welfare mentality impressed upon people from the Keating Labor government that has left us where we are today.

Going back to the concerns people have about the sale of assets, I hate to have to admit that, in some cases, privatisation is the only way to make some operations work, as the current work practices entrenched in the workplace stop the operation from ever becoming financially viable. Quoting from the background to the legislation, I think it is absolutely important that people reading this speech have a firm indication of what the legislation was about. On 1 July 1997, the government executed the first phase of the sale of federal airports with the granting of long‐term leases of major airports at Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth.

Melbourne airport was sold for $1.31 billion to Australia Pacific Airports Corporation, comprising AMP, BAA, Axiom Funds Management and Hastings Fund Management. Brisbane airport was sold for $1.39 billion to Brisbane Airport Corporation Ltd, comprising Amsterdam airport, Commonwealth Bank, Brisbane City Council and the Port of Brisbane Group. Perth airport was sold for $643 million to the Air Australia Development Group, comprising Airport Group Holdings International, Infratil Australia and Hastings Fund Management.

Airports sold on a freehold basis must also continue to operate as airports. The legislation we passed some time ago also ensured that individuals and companies buying airports must use the airports for the original intent. It is absolutely important that people know that, although many of these airports are being sold off or into lease, anybody purchasing them will have to use them for their original intent, which is as an airport air facility. That would be somewhat comforting to many.

The electorate of Capricornia has many options in relation to expanding its use of airports, in particular the need to lengthen the runway at Rockhampton to 3,200 metres. This is in line with the new developments in the Dawson Valley area—the new Nathan Gorge Dam—which should soon be coming on line. The proposal has been put forward and funding has, in some ways, already been announced.

This will bring major benefits to the region, particularly overseas exports. We will have the ability to fly out red claw, fruits, vegetables and flowers to overseas countries. It will be an incredible boost for the Capricornia region. With that in mind, I do not mind pushing the barrow that it is absolutely important that various areas be expanded.

The Capricornia electorate has also grown somewhat. It has physically geographically doubled in size and now includes other areas of Longreach, Winton, Aramac and Barcaldine as well. What would significantly benefit that area is an upgrade to the Longreach airport. This will be an addition in line with our infrastructure strategy put in place to help the western part of the new electorate.

Listening to many of the speakers today, I also find it necessary to comment, as did a previous speaker, the member for Fadden (Mr Jull), in relation to the placement of airports. I feel that governments—local, state or federal—should also legislate to prevent people purchasing housing land particularly around airports. It is absolutely crazy. As far as airports are concerned, they are usually there in the first place. Yet people move to and want to build housing estates, and those sorts of things, right next to the airports. The airport was there first.

It is absolutely crazy people being able to build right next to them. Then, all of a sudden, they start complaining about the noise factor. I guess this is somewhat human nature, because the land values and the housing values would be cheaper at the time. But, at the end of the day, when the land or houses are sold on, all of a sudden we have the problem of people complaining about airport noise. It leaves us in the exact situation we hear about today with places like Essendon, Sydney, and so forth.

I will not dwell on it. There were only a few points in particular that I wished to make in relation to the Airports Legislation Amendment Bill 1997. I understand the opposition has various amendments. As far as I am concerned, the legislation that is put forward by the coalition government is good, solid legislation. It will go a long way to ensuring that airports around this country, through their privatisation and so forth, will give a benefit, and of course a financial boost, to society.

That further proceedings on the bill be conducted in the House.

TITLE.XREF: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (TRUST LOSS AND OTHER DEDUCTIONS) BILL 1997

BREAK.XREF: FAMILY TRUST DISTRIBUTION TAX (PRIMARY LIABILITY) BILL 1997
FAMILY TRUST DISTRIBUTION TAX (SECONDARY LIABILITY) BILL 1997
MEDICARE LEVY CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENT (TRUST LOSS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 October, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Gareth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to you, Mr Chairman. I understand that we are debating cognately the Taxation Laws Amendment (Trust Loss and Other Deductions) Bill 1997 and the package of bills on trust loss and related matters. This package of bills is in fact one of the most important to come before the parliament in the taxation area during the life of this government. It is a little unfortunate to that extent that we find ourselves in the Main Committee rather than in the chamber. Had we been bumped by anything less significant than the native title legislation, my angst might be a little greater than in fact it is.

SPEECH.PARA: I do emphasise the importance of the legislation for two reasons. The measures that it contains and that it addresses are necessary, certainly, to improve the equity of the tax system. It is important for another quite different reason. The process leading to the debate today tells us quite a lot about the government's attitude to tax avoidance, in terms of both the timing and sequencing of this legislation and its substantive content. What it tells us is that the government have deliberately chosen not to come down as heavily on tax avoidance as rhetoric would lead us to suspect—and they might be inclined to do—and certainly not as heavily as Labor had originally proposed in relation to these particular measures.
As to the rhetoric, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has, of course, repeatedly told the parliament that he is going to be tough on tax avoidance. He said on 20 June in Hansard:
I make it clear on behalf of this government that where anomalies and exemptions are being unfairly exploited they will be addressed.
Again on 2 September this year, he said:
The government takes such measures as are required to prevent legitimate taxation liabilities being avoided.
As recently as earlier this month, the rhetoric—the rhetorical charade, more accurately—continued on 2 October, when the Treasurer said:
This government is serious about making sure that corporations—and, indeed, individuals—pay their fair share of tax.

Despite these words and a great many others by the Treasurer, these bills certainly do not match that rhetoric. They have, for a start, had an extraordinary career in terms of the delay that has been involved—I think an almost unprecedented delay—in bringing them to fruition as a significant piece of anti-avoidance legislation.

In government, we recognised the significant problem and we announced a wide ranging package to deal with the abuse of trust losses in the 1995 budget. That announcement was made on 9 May 1995, almost 2½ years ago. We duly introduced legislation into the parliament later in 1995. The opposition sent the legislation to a Senate committee and achieved its objective of delaying consideration of legislation by the Senate until the election intervened early in 1996.

No doubt there were some in the coalition who fervently then hoped that the issue would be dropped after the election. The reasons they might have so hoped will become, I hope, a little clearer in a moment. The issue has not been dropped completely, but there has been an awful lot of ducking and weaving going on, nonetheless, over the last 18 months.

After a deafening silence for five months on the issue, we did see an announcement first of all in the 1996 budget, which affirmed that this government would pursue the issue, albeit with modifications. Six months later, draft legislation was released. A further three months later, a subsequent announcement was made in the 1997 budget which contained further changes from the draft legislation released in February. It has now taken a further five months for this legislation to be presented to the House.

It was introduced at the end of the last two-week sitting period. The government immediately said that they wished to have a quick passage into the Senate. We are happy to oblige with that swift passage of any anti‐avoidance legislation and we are doing that today. But it is a bit rich for this government to be so demanding, given the extraordinary context in which this bill comes before us—the context of endless unjustified delays.

Leaving aside the history of the bills and the delay issue, let me turn to the more substantial question of the substance of the measures before us. These bills will insert rules into the income tax law to limit the circumstances under which trusts can deduct current year and prior year losses and debt deductions. Labor supports such an approach of limiting the use of losses for these purposes without any reservations.

The reason for introducing these limitations is to ensure that the persons who bore the economic effect of the tax losses are the persons who obtain the tax benefits associated with the recouping of those losses against other income. The public policy behind this approach is quite simple and straightforward. People should not be able to avoid their proper tax liabilities by sheltering their income through the use of tax losses incurred by other taxpayers. This has long been accepted in the context of losses incurred by companies. Company losses can only be recouped if the company passes a majority underlying shareholding test, or if the company passes the so‐called `same business' test.

Bearing this in mind, the introduction of a regime to regulate the claiming of losses incurred by trusts is an important and overdue step in securing the direct tax base in Australia. Obviously, the proposed rules that are to apply to the trusts differ somewhat from the regime which applies to companies. However, this generally reflects the differing legal relationships which apply in the case of trusts, rather than a fundamentally different approach to the question of the legitimacy of the recoupment of losses. The key issues now for these bills are not the differences between the treatment of companies and trusts, but rather the treatment within the category of trusts of family trusts—the treatment under the original proposed Labor legislation, and their treatment now in this legislative package. The press release of the Treasurer of 13 May this year—press release No. 42—said:

On 10 February 1997, the Government released an exposure draft legislation on trust loss measures. After receiving comments and submissions, the government has decided to modify the draft legislation to restrict its application . The income injection test will not apply where entities and individuals within a family group inject income into a family trust with losses. This modification will have effect from 7.30pm AEST 9 May 1995 . . .

These words sound innocent enough, perhaps, to someone not familiar with the very complex legislation before us today, but they represent a huge change in the effect of this legislation. Under the original Labor legislation, the income injection rule did not apply to family trusts where a beneficiary of a loss trust introduced income into the trust to be offset against the losses. That concession was allowed because the beneficiary actually bore the economic effect of the loss, as he or she was a beneficiary at the time that the losses were incurred. That was and remains a perfectly appropriate concession.

However where a family member, for example, a brother or a sister, who is not a beneficiary of the trust injected income into the trust to derive the tax benefit of the losses within the trust and then got the income back tax free, then, under our scheme, these anti‐avoidance provisions would apply to that scheme. For examples of these two separate situations, I draw the attention of honourable members to page 171 of the explanatory memorandum for Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995, examples 3 and 4, and I seek leave to table the relevant extract.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The rules under this proposed legislation that we are dealing with today, by contrast with the 1995 legislation, propose that any member of the family group as defined—and that includes spouses, children, grandparents, uncles, aunts, nephews, nieces and their spouses and, indeed, any entities, like companies, which are wholly owned by any of them—can inject income into any other family member's trust and thereby gain the benefit of the losses that may have been incurred by that other trust.

BREAK.PARA: Clearly, this is a huge change and it is not one that the opposition is happy about. Members should be able to imagine that the wealthy families of Australia where many members of the broader family have significant assets will now be able to traffic in trust losses among themselves, utterly immune from the application of this legislation. They will be largely, if not always completely, exempt from these new provisions. That is simply not fair by any reasonable analysis.

This change is being dressed up as a family friendly change, but it is really a tax avoidance friendly change. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) speaking to Alan Jones on 14 August this year summed it up rather well. He said:

I mean, it is aggravating in the extreme if you are a PAYE tax battler, you're having your money taken out each week when you hear of people through all sorts of dodges, the cash economy as well as some people at the big end of town not paying their fair share.

For once, Prime Minister, amen to that. The opposition doubts that many PAYE tax battlers are going to be very happy at all to learn about this brand new tax dodge authorised by the government—the content of this legislation—now available to the big end of town. Most families will not be able to benefit from these new rorts for family trusts because, of course, ordinary people will not have any connection with a family trust.

So this legislation has not only been delayed in an unprecedented fashion; it has been dramatically watered down in some crucial respects so far as family trusts are concerned. The delay shows a lack of political will, to put it the most gently, on behalf of the government. The watering down shows a lack of fairness and commitment to treating all taxpayers equally.

When both of these things occur, the opposition is entitled to ask why. An examination of the pecuniary interests register for ministers and parliamentary secretaries, leave aside members more generally, is very instructive indeed in this regard. It appears that up to 13 ministers and six parliamentary secretaries—19 altogether; well over half of the whole government front bench—in fact have some kind of family trust in relation to their immediate family. I say `up to' advisedly because there simply is not sufficient information in a number of cases in relation to the pecuniary interests register to enable a judgment to be unequivocally made that the trust disclosed is in fact a family trust in the accepted sense—that is, one in which both the trustees and the beneficiaries come from a single family group. Nonetheless, it is apparent, even with that caveat, that family trusts are alive and well in this particular front bench.

So far as cabinet ministers are concerned, we have: Minister Anderson, with the AJ Robertson Family Trust; Minister Downer, with the Downer Family Trust; Minister Fischer, with the TA Fischer Trust; Minister Hill, with the RD & DM Hill Family Trust; Minister McLachlan, with the McLachlan Kilbride Trust, the JM Lee Trust, which apparently relates to his spouse, and the AA McLachlan Children's Trust; and Attorney‐General Williams, with the Pied Piper Trust, going to investment and administrative services but, on the face of it, quite likely to be a family trust—although, as I indicated, one cannot be completely sure of that.

So far as ministers in the outer ministry are concerned, we have: Minister Ellison disclosing the CM Ellison trust; Minister Herron disclosing the Herron Family Trust; Minister Moylan disclosing the JE Spark Family Trust and the Judi Moylan Family Trust; Senator Parer disclosing the Parer Family Trust; Minister Scott disclosing the Crochdantigh Family Trust; Minister Vanstone, with the Southern Rural Property Trust, which may not be a family trust, I readily acknowledge, but it does seem a likely candidate because of the nature of the investment property involved on the disclosure form; and with Minister Thomson, we have the Peter Thomson Family Provision Trust.

Then, so far as the parliamentary secretaries are concerned, we have Secretary Abbott, with the Abbott Family Trust and the Tony Abbott Family Trust. We have Senator Brownhill, with what seems to be—the writing is not quite up to the occasion—the Millowritz, the Merrilong and the Merrilong Pastoral Co. discretionary trusts, which appear to have the character of family trusts, as I have described them, but may not in practice, on closer examination, I acknowledge. We have Senator Ian Macdonald with the ID Macdonald Family Trust. We have Mr Ronaldson with the MJC & CM Ronaldson Family Trust. We have Senator Tambling, with the Tambling Trust No. 1, and we have Senator Troeth with the Judith Troeth Family Trust.

For the sake of completeness, I do add that, on the Labor Party side, the pecuniary interest register does disclose that one of our frontbenchers—one only—is the beneficiary of a family trust. But I understand that that person is in the process of changing that status at the moment.

The story is a straightforward one. I do not make any point about the illegality, or anything else, of people holding such trusts. But when you are talking about a piece of legislation coming before this parliament which dramatically waters down the impact on family trusts of a major piece of tax avoidance legislation, it is entirely reasonable for the wider community, and us specifically in the opposition, to be asking why.

The conflict of interest that is involved here screams out for notice and screams out for explanation. The interests of up to six cabinet ministers, up to seven members of the outer ministry and up to six parliamentary secretaries are clearly directly affected by this legislation. There is an issue of conflict of interest involved here and it is one the government really does have to explain.

I make clear, for the record, that the Treasurer himself appears to have no personal conflict of interest here in the sense that his return discloses no such family trust nor, and I repeat again, is it in any way illegal or wrong for anyone to have a family trust of the kind that I have been describing.

But there is clearly a conflict of interest involved when members of a government, particularly when there are so many of them, are considering such legislation in the cabinet or in the other processes of parliamentary approval. What the opposition would like to know and what the government might, I hope, be inclined to tell us is: did the relevant members of cabinet with family trusts exclude themselves from the consideration of these issues or at the very least make clear the nature of the conflict of their interest when the matter was debated around the cabinet table? In answering that question the government might also tell us whether such a level of conflict of interest is compatible with any government fairly and properly evaluating revenue issues of this kind and whether or not it is compatible with a government acting against what had already been announced by its predecessor to water down significantly a piece of legislation which would have bitten into the kind of financial returns that could be derived from these trusts.

It is also an interesting question to ask as to how the government proposes to handle this conflict of interest question when it comes into the parliament proper. I know there is no longer the same obligation since the introduction of the register and related matters for people to stand up in parliament and disclose these interests before matters are voted upon, but in all decency one would expect and hope that that would be done on this occasion. The second reading amendment I will move at the conclusion of this speech will give members an opportunity to make their position clear in this respect.

The Prime Minister really does, personally, have a lot to answer for on all these matters. One cannot help but raise a quizzical eyebrow as to why it was that the Prime Minister said to a coalition meeting, not in relation to family trusts, but trusts more generally, on 23 September that, as reported in the press of the next day, trusts for small‐ and medium-sized business entities would be okay in the context of the tax reform process. When I challenged him in the House on 1 October on just that issue and whether it was proposed to walk away from the proposal that trusts be treated the same as companies for tax purposes, we had a Prime Minister ducking and weaving and retreating to the general formula that he did not want to do anything to disadvantage the small business community but certainly leaving open the question of there being some differential advantage given to trusts of that character. Again, given the prevalence of trusts, not only family trusts but other kinds of trusts as well, within the ranks of the coalition front bench one cannot help but legitimately ask to what extent are private interest considerations governing this government's consideration of the public policy principles involved in these particular matters.

What is the Labor Party going to do about this legislation in the light of this concern that we have? I have to say that legislation of this kind always poses something of a dilemma for responsible oppositions. On the one hand we are, as I hope I have been making very clear, very concerned about the direction which the government has gone in significantly limiting the scope of this bill. We do not support, as I have made clear, these changes to effectively exempt family trusts from the income injection regime. We do know that this will, quite apart from anything else, cost the Commonwealth significant revenue, probably at least tens of millions of dollars each year.

In that respect I say further that many members of the accounting and tax professions have contacted the opposition on various aspects of these bills. Given the extraordinarily protracted history of them and their significant retrospective effect as well as their substantive impact, we have signalled to the industry that we will support a Senate inquiry into the bill.

We do want to see the issues explored. In particular, we want to see explored in the Senate inquiry what scope there might be for amendments of the provisions of the present bill, at least so far as the injection of income is concerned. On the other hand, against these sorts of considerations and our very real concern for the legislation, we do recognise that it may well be unreasonable for the Senate, or parliament itself, to now change the rules retrospectively, or at least all the way back to 9 May 1995, to tighten the income injection test.

Taxpayers have been relying on the more recent public announcements of the Treasurer in respect of this matter. It is also the case that taxpayers and their organisations have been engaged in a long consultation process in good faith. It may well, under these circumstances, be unreasonable to change the rules significantly with retrospective effect. It is part of the dilemma that is always associated with tax legislation by press release, but it is a dilemma that affects every government, not just this one.

The other consideration that the opposition has to bear in mind is that we do regard the passage of this legislation, overall, as generally very desirable despite the particular problems that I have been focussing on today. It is the case that around $500 million in revenue is expected from these bills over the four years until 1998‐99. We certainly do not want to put that revenue at risk by trying to fix up the equity of one piece of the legislation but then perhaps have the government walk away from the legislation altogether as a result.

Subject to further consideration by the opposition in the context of what might emerge from the Senate inquiry, I indicate today that Labor will not be opposing the bill in its present form in the House of Representatives and we are not likely to seek to oppose it in the Senate. However, we certainly will be reviewing the operation of these rules when we come back to government, sooner now rather than later, with a view to tightening this legislation to ensure that all avoidance is stamped out.

I make no bones about making very clear our intention to home in on this particular area in exactly the same way that we did in 1995. It is very difficult to embark upon these courses, particularly complex amendments, complex tax legislation, when you are in opposition, but when you are in government it is a different story, and it will be.

There are a few general points I would like to make about the tax debate because I think the opposition's position and the extent to which we have been cooperative in the enterprise of tax reform has perhaps not significantly been acknowledged. The government is currently undertaking, as we all know, a secret bureaucratic exercise, crunching the numbers, to develop various options for tax reform. It has refused our invitation to make that information public so that the public at large, and we in particular, can be well informed of the actual options and make some intelligent choices, or better informed choices, accordingly. We will always make intelligent ones, but a little bit more information helps. The government, however, pretends that Labor is against reform and that it is turning its back on the whole reform process. Nothing could be further from the truth.

The only basic change that we have ruled out, and we have ruled it out absolutely, is the adoption of a GST. That has infuriated the government because as we have always known, the implementation of a GST is the only real objective of this whole exercise. That was a point that was confirmed by the thrust of the speech by the Treasurer to the MTIA earlier this week, a limp and lacklustre speech though it was and for which the applause in unprecedented fashion died away by the time he had left the platform, quite apart from by the time he had actually reached his seat. I hope that the Treasurer derived some message from the deafening silence with which his approach to these matters was greeted on that occasion.

The opposition has taken the position of not attempting in any way to derail the reform task force procedure. We have not availed ourselves of the many opportunities that there have been over the last few months to beat up issues, and neither have we sought to use the procedures of this parliament to delay or frustrate important tax matters which have arisen.

Let me give some examples of this to buttress the point. For a start, the resolution of the half decade long problem concerning the impact of the petroleum resource rent tax on Victoria was dealt with cooperatively by me with the Treasurer, exactly as it should have been on an issue of that significance, that is, on a completely apolitical basis. The necessary legislation was dealt with very swiftly in the national interest. No attempt was made by us to derail the settlement or misinform the public.

A second example I give goes to the aftermath of the Ha and Lim and Walter Hammond judgments where, as we will all recall from recent memory, a fiscal crisis arose for the states and territories. Around a sixth of the revenue base of these governments was eliminated by that High Court case and the prospect of gigantic repayments of past tax collections loomed. Here surely was a heaven‐sent opportunity for politics to override the governance and for the opposition to wreak a degree of havoc. A huge tax rescue package of around one per cent of GDP was needed quickly to sure up confidence and the financial position of the states and territories.

Again I remind the government and public that we gave the legislation immediate passage through both houses of parliament because it was indisputably in the national interest to do so. The government bungled the compensation payments issue arising from new safety net arrangements so badly that the Queensland situation was only solved last week. We had a few things to say about that on the way through but we did not in any way undermine that process, even though there were many opportunities to do so. Again, I make the point that all the other tax bills which have come before this parliament in the term of this government dealing with tax avoidance have been passed without demur or delay by the opposition.

Earlier this week, a bill tightening the rules concerning foreign source income was passed with full opposition support through the Senate. There is also another tax bill before the Senate at the moment, Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 , which contains a number of important anti‐avoidance measures including the very difficult one of ensuring that charitable trusts are not used as vehicles for tax avoidance. Honourable members from a number of causes will probably recall receiving representations from charities and other religious and community groups concerned that the initial draft of this legislation was drawn too widely and would have impacted on the legitimate activities of those important bodies.

Although there was an opportunity to make some play of all of this, the opposition, supporting the principle of clamping down on illegitimate tax avoidance, took the decision not to play that political game but rather to support the proper tightening of the net while at the same time ensuring that bona fide charities are not detrimentally affected. I would submit that that is about as good a record on tax avoidance issues as any opposition has had in recent decades, at least, certainly in my memory.

I contrast our cooperative stance with the various coalition oppositions over the last 13 years where every decent tax measure that I can recall—including capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax, the proper tax of foreign source income and improving the equity of retirement benefit taxation—was opposed root and branch. I note the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) busily scribbling as he wants to leap back into the fray on some of those issues. The point is that those opposite have had an ample record over the years, particularly their years in opposition, as wreckers of decent tax reform. That has not been the case for us. We come to the tax reform debate, as with everything else, with completely clean hands.

The final point I make, it will have to be pretty briskly, is that a number of holes in the tax base have been introduced by this present government, which really do point up the breathtaking hypocrisy of claims of the kind that continue to be made that we are not interested in the reform or renovation of the tax system. Rather than shoring up the base, the government has introduced, for a start, a whole raft of concessions including the family tax initiative of around $1 billion a year; the health insurance rebate of around $600 million a year; the tax rebate for wealthy self‐funded retirees worth $70 million a year; the capital gains tax concessions for small business worth about $400 million; and a further $50 million in fringe benefits tax concessions. Many of these are individually defensible, of course, in policy terms, but, cumulatively, they add up to a huge impact on the tax base: in fact, around $2 billion per year.

Add to that the indefensible and ludicrous savings rebate proposal, which is going to cost a further $2 billion within a very short time, and you have got an example of just what kind of difficulties this government is getting into as it attacks various aspects of the tax base rather than broadening it in order to make life easier for everybody else. This bill before us provides a further example of a hole being deliberately made or at least being deliberately left open which will facilitate the lower payment of tax by those with considerable opportunity to make their proper contribution to the community. I am referring again, in particular, to the quarantining job that has been done for take home payers on family trust situations. Accordingly, I conclude by moving a second reading amendment which has been circulated in my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey, Wilson, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The chamelons of the federal parliament are out here today—

SPEECH.PARA: Not once has the Labor spokesperson down there stood up and put a case about a nursing home in the western suburbs or Frankston in the Melbourne area or somewhere like that. No, no, no. We have to look at what is actually going on and whether, for instance, something like a trust is initially designed as a tax avoidance measure or is put there for other purposes. The reality, and the fact, is that if a person or a family today has some assets of a tangible nature, it is almost imperative that they have a trust structure to protect those assets.

The great problems of today relate to marriage break‐up and all sorts of things that can put family assets, created by past generations or by living older generations, at great risk. Many people have entered into trust arrangements to guarantee the protection and the transition of those particular properties. There is nothing wrong with that. They are not in the business of dodging tax. For many in our present economic circumstances, they have very few worries about tax because they are not making any profits.

We hear the shadow Treasurer today complaining about a family member gaining a tax deduction because that person has put some of his or her own taxable income back into the family trust because the trust has made losses. A loss is a loss is a loss. There is a suggestion that in every case this money is fed in and passed back. I bet it is! The bank manager will not allow that to happen, because it frequently goes in to pay off the debts that the trust company has accumulated by making trading losses. It does not come back. I am not sure where there would be a small family trust where the money would be returned, if it was put in there to cover losses. It is put in there to cover creditors, or it is put in there to repay the bank, and it is not available for repayment.

If a family member contributes more money to a trust so that, for instance, those battling creditors can be paid or so that the bank debt can be reduced, why should that family member not get a tax deduction? They have lost the money. If you say that you want to prevent some recycling process whereby that occurs, you had better identify it. But the reality is that it does not happen or that it happens on few occasions. What are we getting pushed around on?

We have said that a family trust is a very special organisation. What are its tax benefits in the broader sense? It, as a trust, does not attract taxation. All the profits, if they exist, that are available to it must be distributed and they are taxed in the hands of the beneficiaries. We are told it would be much better if they were treated as companies; but companies cannot give the level of protection that I just mentioned for family assets which need to be protected from outside problems.

But how does a company work? The company pays the tax, and the beneficiary—otherwise known as a shareholder—does not. In net terms, where is the great benefit that is going to accrue to the revenue? It is not going to, except for one thing. Of course the Labor Party are very conscious of this, and they did it everywhere they could: there is a small advantage—where profits exist—of bringing the taxation revenue forward. The Labor Party did that wherever they possibly could, and the outcome was that further and further pressure was put on small family businesses to pay their tax sooner and sooner and, of course, the reality is that they did not have money to expand their business—and we wonder why today they are not creating the employment that they did in the past!

But let us get back to where we stand, because the shadow Treasurer also complained bitterly about our not inviting the Labor Party into our policy preparation. I must go back through my 17 years here to see when we ever got such an invitation from them. It would be fairly unique. In fact, it would have been a case of `"Come into my parlour," said the spider to the fly.' They probably would have given us some bung documents. But the realities are that—

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't have understood them, that's for sure!

—I understand; and, in fact, any of you blokes that think I do not are even bigger fools than I think you are. I encourage you to think I am an idiot. John Dawkins did, and I destroyed his political career: so be my guest!
—Since when does John Howard do that?

—You can have any example you like, but do not ever be so silly. It is up to you. I welcome it, because I think fools are to be found in many places and I have just been looking at a couple. The facts of life are, of course, that when it comes to revenue collection there are some requirements. The first is that those from whom you want the revenue have to have made the profit. We keep getting these wonderful pictures painted by the tax commissioner. The member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), who was the Treasurer at the time, told us at the last election that he had the perfect solution to the revenue problem. The tax commissioner had told him he was going to collect $800 million from 100 taxpayers who were apparently using the trust system to avoid $800 million per year in tax. How much did we get? The legislation passed; we got nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: That tax provision has been available to the Commissioner of Taxation since the announcement of the Treasurer (Mr Costello). The realities are that he got nothing and he will get half of that in terms of what small business could provide. Small business does not pay much tax because it is not making much money. It battles and struggles away. It still has accumulated losses relating to the recession we had to have—remember that one—when people were driven out of business in their thousands. These are the arguments.

There is no money of substance and substantial amounts of revenue available. More importantly, there is the suggestion that where there is an outstanding loan and some revenue injected into the trust by an individual family member, who may have other income by way of salary or profits from an outside investment, that is not a legitimate expense on 95 per cent at least of the occasions and it would be money lost forever. It is not a tax scam. It is propping up the family business and people clearly should, as we have said, be able to obtain a tax deduction. If, sometime in the future, they get a payment, they will pay tax on it. There is nothing wrong with that. That is when the business makes money. But if the business is losing money, what is wrong with people who inject money gaining the benefit of the tax deduction? In fact, we are really talking about artificial ways of raising taxation—wrong ones. A loss is a loss is a loss. That is the way it should be.

We get a few promises also from the shadow Treasurer. Even in this regard, they will review this law. It is a promise they might keep because they do not like small business. Why would you believe the Labor Party on anything it said about tax? Why would you even believe that their current political campaign against the GST would not be turned over the day they got elected because they wanted the money?

It is all on the record. I am not speculating. Those letters l‐a‐w are burned on my brain. I saw the then Prime Minister attack the media and say, `Of course, we will give this tax deduction to the Australian people. It's l‐a‐w.' And what did the Labor Party do? They never got a penny of it. Then you started to rationalise it away in schemes that were never going to work, and that was probably worse. You should have just come in straightaway and said, `We never intended to do it.'

On tax, you told the Australian people that you could manage the economy, you could fix up whatever. The Labor Party have now made a promise about nursing homes. Why believe them on that? But, of course, they will materialise money. They will get $800 million from some very rich people they say.

They said in 1993 they would not increase any taxes to manage their program. And what happened? Six cents a litre on fuel flowed throughout the economy to every item that the pensioner bought in the supermarket, flowed through as a massive disincentive to our car manufacturers and everybody else who had to pay that to produce these vehicles. That is what a VAT is all about. What did they do? They put an extra 2c above that on leaded petrol. It is well known who owns cars that consume leaded petrol—it is the battlers. Then they put two per cent on wholesale sales tax. That is how dishonest they were to the Australian people. We could not even trust your word if you said you were going to put taxes up, let alone put them down and adjust things.

Your attitude to this legislation is totally anti‐small business. They are outside the net of union domination and you do not like them. They do not make large amounts of money. The trust structure is there to ensure that their assets can be protected and it does not prevent them from paying any tax that they could not achieve by other means, including partnerships. But partnerships and companies do not give that protection to family assets which are so necessary today.
Let me come back again to this increase in income tax, which it has been said is the solution to the problems of paying out for nursing homes, or removing nursing home bonds. If someone has a house—

TALK.START.PARA: —No‐one has said that.
—You have said it.
—No‐one has said that. It's absurd.
—Your spokesman has said on the radio that we will get the money from the tax system.
—From taxation.
—Yes, you are going to materialise it again.
—You misrepresented it.
—Order! The honourable member for Wills! The honourable member for O'Connor will direct his comments through the chair.

—Mr Chairman, I am speaking to you now. We will buy him an Arabian outfit and he can become an alchemist, because that is where they think money comes from. You know what you are going to do—the same as you did in 1993. You are going to increase taxes. And where does that always happen? On PAYE people, because they cannot escape. The people of the western suburbs and Frankston, and other parts of our big cities, will see their $400 a week being further eroded while they are trying to pay off a mortgage and while they are trying to educate their kids.

SPEECH.PARA: Who are the beneficiaries they have been speaking of in the last couple of days? The residents of nursing homes in Rose Bay! I have been there only once—to the most expensive restaurant I have ever been to. There are million dollar houses. What a joke! But go back through the Hansard and find one reference to a nursing home in the western suburbs where, of course, most people will not pay any bond at all. They will still get accommodation, and they will be looked after as they should. But for pure political advantage, considering the structure of its constituency, the Labor Party stands up and argues this case. Someone sold a house in Sydney the other day for $14 million. Under Labor's law, which they are defending with a passion, that person would have a free ride into a nursing home.

How can you substantiate that and then say, `We'll get it out of the tax system'? They get up in here day after day and say, `Big business doesn't pay any tax. But we'll get it out of the tax system.' In other words, it will be a bit more of a load on the PAYE mob. They will be giving us a quote on Toorak today. You check the record; not one word, and this is the problem.

It is the same with small business. They are not the wealthy people of Australia. Their incomes are not high. In fact, on many occasions, the wages they struggle to pay every week are about 90 per cent of their revenue. They take home less than most of their individual employees.

Why are you running around trying to cut them off and telling them that, if one of their relatives is prepared to invest a bit of money in their business to keep it solvent, you will not give them a tax deduction? It is just so silly. What we have proposed is quite proper. I am very critical of the campaign—I will go on the record about this—of Mr Carmody, because I do not think the money is there other than, as I said, the biddy might get in six months earlier, again at great cost to certain people, and drive some of them out of their trust structures with other outside effects.

These are the reasons the legislation comes in the form it does. It does set out to prevent certain activities where trusts were probably used to avoid taxation. For goodness sake, the shadow Treasurer, the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), chose to read out a list of the trust holdings of some members of cabinet. I have already mentioned John Dawkins. He was capitalising interests so he did not have to pay tax. Based on his affairs, he would have made a fortune as a tax adviser.

Do not ever think—as you learnt the other day when you attacked certain people in other areas—that your own side is not in the business of tax avoidance.
