If they do, they will pay tax on it. Surely, that is the principle that applies to taxation. When people make a profit, they pay tax. If by some act, they compensate a loss, they have made a loss. If they use other revenue, why should they pay PAYE on some money when they are going to invest it, or put it back in a business, to cover a loss? It is simple arithmetic.

BREAK.PARA: In the last 20 seconds, I will say something about cooperative stances. A VAT takes the burden off the people that builds in from the iron ore mine right down to the delivery door of the taxes that build into our manufactured cost. In a global economy, while we build taxes into manufactured costs, as we most definitely do, we are destroying people's chances to have jobs. If the Labor Party cannot understand that, they do not deserve any office in the parliament. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has given us a great address in favour of tax avoidance and that is not surprising. As he has a trust of his own, it is not surprising that he should be on the side of the tax avoiders rather than on the side of ordinary PAYE taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: He asks us: why should trusts be taxed in the same way as companies are taxed? I will come to this as an issue in a moment. He also asked us: what is wrong with someone, apart from immediate family, injecting money into a trust and then being able to get the tax benefit from it? The point here is that Labor has no problem with those who are beneficiaries of a trust—with those family members who are part of a family trust—being able to get the benefit of income injections because, where these are being offset against losses, it is they who have to carry the losses. Clearly, if you have someone who is outside that immediate family trust structure—such as a brother or another relative—if that person is allowed to inject income into the trust and then say, `That income can be offset against the tax losses of that trust' that opens up the prospect for tax avoidance, for tax abuses and for rorts.

The member for O'Connor raised the issue: why should trusts be taxed in the same way as companies? I would like to draw his attention to the Financial Review of 25 September. In the Chanticleer column, Ivor Ries says:
John Howard's decision not to mount a crackdown on trusts used by family businesses will be sold to the public as a concession to the `battlers' of the small business world.

Unfortunately, the reverse is true. The decision to allow some businesses to minimise or avoid tax entirely (because they operate through trusts) while the bulk of the small business community operates through companies (and pay corporate tax), is blatantly unfair, discriminatory and can only further erode faith in the equity of the tax system.

It's a shocking, retrograde and gutless move. Howard should be forced to impose a level tax playing field for all small and medium‐sized businesses, regardless of the legal vehicle they use to operate a business. At present only the smarties and hard core avoiders are winning.

I also draw the member for O'Connor's attention to the speech of Tax Commissioner Michael Carmody in recent times. Michael Carmody pointed out that the present arrangements allowed one wealthy individual to collect $19 million tax free in one year. An article in the Australian stated that Mr Carmody said:

There was a strong case to tax some or all trusts in the same way as companies, a move which officials believe could deliver hundreds of millions, possibly $1 billion, in extra revenue to the government.
He further went on to say:
It was not fair that some people could pay no tax on profits that they took out of trusts, while investors in business, including mum‐and‐dad shareholders, paid tax on "equivalent proceeds".

He gave these examples: $19 million taken out of trusts by one person who paid no tax on them whatsoever—notwithstanding the belief of the honourable member for O'Connor; and another collecting $5 million a year tax free over at least three years.

BREAK.PARA: The most recent figures show there are some 367,000 trusts, 495,000 companies and 580,000 business partnerships in Australia as of 1994‐95. So it is a major matter in terms of Australia's taxation system and the equity and efficiency of that system.
I would like to take the House to some of the remarks made by Michael Carmody in that address. He said:

At a broader fairness level, why should a person who invests in a business conducted through a trust and sees the value of the business increase be able to take out proceeds free of tax where the ordinary investor, whose ability to invest in business is generally limited to share purchases, pays tax on equivalent proceeds.

Is that a fair system? Is that one that has integrity? Are they not reasonable questions for us to raise? He goes on to express some concern about the use of trusts by wealthy individuals for property development purposes. He said:

These groups commonly state that they are in the business of buying, developing and renting properties, but are not in the business of selling the properties. As a result, the profits on the sale of properties are generally not being returned as income.
So he identifies a number of common features of these property development groups. He said:

The groups arrange their affairs so that one trust or company owns, develops and sells only a few properties. In some groups every new property is developed via a separate entity, usually a trust. Second, that the structure of the property development groups appears to feature multiple layers of trusts companies and a number of single purpose entities. Third, that the trusts are generally companies under the direct or indirect control of the wealthy individual. Fourth, that the group centralise their financing arrangements in a banking entity within the group. And fifth, that generally there are substantial losses predominantly from interest expenses within the groups to offset assessable receipts.

Using that kind of device, we see high wealth individuals in Australia today avoiding paying their fair share of tax obligations and, regrettably, the government shows a reluctance to get into this area. It says that the tax base has broken down; it is irreparable; nothing can be done about it, and we have to introduce GST. Whereas, the fact is that the government is not fair dinkum. It is not really trying as far as tax avoidance is concerned.

This package of bills is important on two counts: firstly, because the measures it contains are necessary to improve the equity of the tax system and, secondly, because the process leading to the bills before the House is indicative of the approach of this government in dealing with tax avoidance issues.

The government has chosen to come down lightly on tax avoidance compared with Labor's original proposal of 1995. This is despite the fact that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has repeatedly told the House that he is tough on tax avoidance—and a few quotes suffice to demonstrate that. On 20 June 1996 the Treasurer said:
I make it clear on behalf of this government that where anomalies and exemptions are being unfairly exploited, they will be addressed.
On 2 September this year he said:
The government takes such measures as are required to prevent legitimate taxation liabilities being avoided.
Earlier this month, on 2 October, he continued this little rhetorical charade, saying:
This government is serious about making sure that corporations and, indeed, individuals pay their fair share of tax.

Yet despite these words, and many others from the Treasurer, these bills have had an extraordinarily long period of gestation in coming before the parliament. Labor had recognised trafficking in trust losses as a significant problem and back on 9 May 1995, almost 2½ years ago, we announced a wide‐ranging package of measures to deal with that.

We introduced that legislation into the parliament in 1995. The opposition sent the legislation off to a Senate committee and they achieved their objective of delaying consideration of the legislation by the Senate until the election intervened. They were not fair dinkum about balancing the books. They were not at all interested in protecting the revenue when they were in opposition.

No doubt there were some in the coalition who hoped that the issue would be dropped after the election. It certainly got moved into the slow lane. After a deafening silence of five months on the issue, we saw an announcement in the 1996 budget which said that the government would pursue it, but with modifications. We had to wait another six months before we saw the draft legislation. We had to wait a further three months before we got a subsequent announcement, in the 1997 budget, that there would be further changes to the legislation, and five more months before the legislation has come before the House. Ironically, given that it was introduced at the end of the last two‐week sitting period, we have the government immediately demanding a quick passage into and through the Senate.

The opposition is in fact happy to oblige with the swift passage of anti‐avoidance legislation, as we are doing today—you can see that the thing is being debated in the Main Committee. But it is just a bit rich for this government, having seen the legislation first in 1995, to come into the parliament now and demand that the bill be fast‐tracked.

I also want to make a few remarks about the general issue of tax reform. The government is not prepared to make its work on tax reform public, but it says that Labor is against tax reform. What honourable members need to understand, and the public needs to understand, is that there is a lot more to tax reform than GST. But the government is not interested in that. They say, `We are in favour of tax reform.' But when you come to them and say, `What do you mean? What do you propose?' it is GST. When we say, `We are against GST. We don't support GST. What else are you interested in?' there is nothing else. In their view, tax reform is the same as GST.

The Treasurer has said that all tax options are on the table, everything will be considered by the government. But when you listen to the government, particularly the Treasurer in question time on issues such as death duties, it is blindingly obvious that the coalition themselves have ruled out many taxation option issues. So there is not, in fact, any open‐minded approach to the revenue issues by this government, merely a cynical attempt to mislead those in the Australian community such as the welfare sector, ACOSS, churches, and so on, into thinking that they are fair dinkum about broad‐ranging tax reform, when they are only interested in GST.

The opposition has not attempted to derail the reform task force procedure, nor have we sought to use the procedures of the parliament to delay or frustrate important tax matters that have arisen. We have had some examples come through the parliament in recent times. We had resolution of the half decade long problem concerning the impact of the petroleum resource rent tax on Victoria. That was dealt with by the shadow Treasurer and the Treasurer on a completely apolitical basis. The legislation was dealt with swiftly in the national interest. No attempt was made to derail the settlement or to misinform the public.

Recently, we also had the Ha and Lim and Walter Hammond judgments concerning business franchise fees for petroleum, alcohol and cigarettes. Following those judgments, there was a fiscal crisis for the states and territories. Those decisions threatened about a sixth of the revenue base of those governments, and the prospect of gigantic repayments of past tax collections loomed. But, once again, the opposition gave the federal legislation immediate passage through both houses of this parliament because it was in the national interest to do so. I note that the government bungled the compensation payments issue arising from the new safety net arrangements so badly that the Queensland situation was only resolved last week. But, again, federal Labor did not in any way undermine that process.

All of the other bills dealing with tax avoidance which have come before this parliament during the term of this government have been passed by the opposition. Just earlier this week, a bill tightening the rules for foreign source income was passed with full opposition support through the Senate. There is also another tax bill before the Senate at present— Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 . That contains some important anti‐avoidance measures, including the issue of ensuring that charitable trusts are not used as vehicles for tax avoidance. Once again, the opposition has played a responsible role. We have not been endeavouring to play a political game. We have endeavoured to support the proper tightening of the net, while ensuring that bona fide charities are not detrimentally affected.

That is the strongest record on taxation issues that any opposition has had for many years and it ought to be contrasted with the government's record on tax reform during their 13 years in opposition. They opposed every decent measure—capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, proper taxation of foreign source income, improving the equity of retirement benefit taxation and all those things. The Liberal Party were the wreckers of decent tax reform.

Furthermore, we find that we have a government which says we need to broaden the tax base. That is their argument in favour of GST: we need to broaden the tax base. And yet, at the same time, it has introduced concessions which have undermined the tax base. We have what is described as family tax initiative, worth a billion dollars a year; health insurance rebate, worth around $600 million a year; capital gains tax concessions for business, worth almost $400 million a year; and another $50 million a year in fringe benefits tax concessions. Those concessions alone are of the order of $2 billion per year and you have also got a savings rebate proposal which will cost a further $2 billion a year within a few years.

After only two budgets, the Treasurer has punched a $4 billion hole in the income tax base of the nation. At the same time, he runs around saying, `Oh, the base is broken and marginal tax rates are too high, so we're going to have to hit all those families out there with a GST.' People who now do not have to pay tax on food are going to have to pay it. They are going to have to pay the tax on clothing, on haircuts and on visits to sport and entertainment. They are going to have pay an extra tax.

This bill provides a further example of a hole being deliberately made, or at least deliberately left open, which will facilitate payment of less tax by those who are best off. By definition, battlers generally do not have trusts. For the very few that do have trusts, by definition those trusts do not have substantial assets in them. It is clear that the government does not intend to seriously crack down on tax avoidance via trusts. It was clear from the assurances of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) given to the party room that the government was not going to, in his words, significantly disadvantage the small business community. But, as I made clear before, there are many in small business who are paying company tax rates on their income and they are missing out as a result of others who are managing to avoid their fair share of tax.

The Prime Minister was unable to give a satisfactory answer to the question asked of him by the shadow Treasurer on 1 October, asking him to explain to the parliament why some small businesses should be allowed to minimise or avoid tax entirely because they operate through trusts, while the bulk of the small business community—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 12.53 p.m. to 4.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was speaking in support of the second reading amendment moved by the opposition. It may be helpful simply to recap by reiterating the significance of that amendment. It says, firstly, the House should condemn the government for the delay in introducing this important legislation; secondly, for watering down Labor's fair approach to stopping trafficking in trust losses; thirdly, for reducing the equity of the Australian taxation system by providing tax benefits to wealthy families which are not available to ordinary PAYE taxpayers and, fourthly, acting inconsistently with its stated tax reform aim of broadening the direct tax base.

BREAK.PARA: What we have here is a situation where the government has watered down the legislation which Labor introduced in 1995 and which they failed to pass. As a result of this, you will find that family trusts will continue to be used as a vehicle for tax avoidance, where relatives who are not part of the immediate family and do not have to be involved in any losses under the ordinary family trust structure are able to inject income into those family trusts and avoid paying tax as a result.

We believe there is no equity about that. We do not think that it helps the government maintain this nation's income tax base. We are highly critical of the government for not engaging in a serious crackdown on tax avoidance which would enable the income tax base to be protected. We think it is highly hypocritical of the government, through legislation such as this and other measures which have come before the parliament, to allow holes to remain and develop and to make some holes of its own in the nation's income tax base, and then come back to the people of Australia and say, `The tax base is in shreds; what we require is a GST.' As I indicated before, a GST is going to impact on those who can least afford it. It will involve taxes on food; it will involve taxes on clothing; it will involve taxes on people who want to be involved in sporting functions, entertainment and things of that nature.

It will hit older people severely. They are people who have gone into the work force, worked all their lives under a regime of relatively high income taxes and relatively low sales taxes. They are not able to go back into the work force and earn more money. It will also impact on small businesses who will have to act as tax collectors in circumstances where presently they do not have to be involved in the sales tax regime. I commend the opposition's amendment to the House and urge that all members support it.
