SPEECH.PARA: It is something that Labor failed to grasp in the 35 years that it drove business offshore. In that time it made our local businesses less profitable and allowed permanent jobs to fall away and be replaced by unsure casual placements as business doubted its future in this country. It is fundamental that you must be able to make a profit in this country to attract business. You cannot seek to tax people out of existence.

By seeking those at the big end of town, you effectively allow them to renegotiate their legal status and take advantage of some other tax minimising scheme. However, small businesses do not have that advantage and, by introducing draconian legislation, which Labor sought to do, it was simply going to hit small business.

Much has been made of the taxpayer who made $90 million and paid one per cent tax. That is still a lot more tax than I paid this year, and I am in the top 15 per cent of money earners in this country. Frequently, by seeking 36 per cent of everything, we end up with no investment, no jobs, no circulation of wealth, no R&D, and loss of world standings in health, standards of living and share of offshore markets.

Ireland, on the other hand, has set in place a tax structure guaranteeing 10 per cent company tax for new investment in information technology until the year 2010, and this was done by a united front. With that stable tax regime in place, 40 per cent of US investment in Europe in the last year went to Ireland. That is what we can achieve with cooperation from both sides on the issue of tax reform.

The contribution of the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) to the tax reform debate was to reiterate that Labor opposes a GST. In other words, they want the same tax regime which they had spent 13 years developing, and which they had in place when they left government. They are not interested in tax reform. He carps about the family tax initiative, the health insurance rebate, the savings rebate and the capital gains tax relief for small business eating into our tax base to the tune of $4 billion.

Let me inform the member for Wills that the residents of Lindsay who qualify for those tax breaks—those on low incomes, those blue‐collar battlers that Labor has for so many years said that it represented—are really grateful for the $1,000 per annum that those rebates represent in their pockets, and not in the pocket of a government which continually spent more than it took in consolidated revenue.

Why is it that a person on $30,000 a year, with three kids, has less disposable income than someone in a similar position on welfare? Is it unreasonable for someone who works 40 hours a week to demand to be $100, $200 or $300 better off than someone who does not? With significant tax reform, this can happen. But the opposition is not interested in talking about tax reform.

What if you do not pay any tax after the age of 65? Wouldn't that please our ageing population, considering that we are getting more and more elderly? What if there was no provisional tax? Wouldn't that please our small businesses? Yet, those opposite do not want to be part of any tax reform discussion. They do not want to provide a regime like Ireland's, they do not want to encourage investment, and they do not want permanent jobs growth. They are not looking at anywhere where the government can save money and offer any sort of tax relief.

Instead, they say, `We don't want a GST.' That is their entire contribution to the tax debate—`We don't want a GST.' I caution against a move away from the PAYE tax base in the modern era. The thing about a GST is that the `S' stands for services, and most services into the next century are able to be transmitted down a telephone wire from anywhere in the world: banking services, finance services, travel services, legal services, architectural services, computer software, network maintenance, education—you can get a degree from Harvard without putting a foot in the United States—and health diagnoses. These days, people in rural areas who are suffering can be diagnosed by Macquarie Street specialists via video conferencing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Telemedicine.

—That is right, telemedicine. If you are getting all of those services offshore, there goes half your goods and services tax. Our side of government is slightly more visionary than that. We need tax reform—major tax reform—to cope with the fast changing technological age. We would like to do it with the cooperation of the opposition. But they oppose. They obstruct. They run scare campaigns and misinform the public on how critical tax reform is to the future of this country. It is not about a GST. It is about how we do business in the future and what we do when broadband satellite data connections are available.

SPEECH.PARA: The world is our oyster but, if Labor continues down the track that Australia resoundingly rejected on 2 March 1996, we will not be at the table of the world's feasts. We will be the waiters, the bus boys and the shoe shines at that feast. This bill seeks to protect our tax base and seeks to close loopholes in the structure of trusts whereby trusts can deduct current year and prior year losses, especially where the owners of the trust at the time of the loss are not the owners taking advantage of the tax break.

It is not designed to strangle small business, and that has been assured to us in the party room and at the committee stages of this bill. I hope the tax commissioner takes note of that intention when making public rulings on this bill. Why is it that Michael Carmody can interpret legislation without a court room and without reference to this place for disallowance in the manner of regulations to legislation?

The tax commissioner, effectively, is legislating with no mandate from the people. A good example of this is in the matter of J. K. Williams in my electorate. He is an ordinary taxpayer, a small businessman with no law degree or advice on tax. And I think the size of this bill has to be mentioned. It is about a centimetre thick and has been added to the already cumbersome, complex and heavy Income Tax Assessment Act. J. K. Williams is no lawyer. He is no tax expert and I doubt whether many tax experts would be proficient in every aspect of that entire piece of legislation. On the advice of his bankers and his accountants and in regard to what everyone else in the business was doing at time, he bought a grader using an investment allowance, as prescribed in the tax act. He entered the contract before the cut‐off date. The gear was delivered before the cut‐off date.

In that intervening time, because he did not actually draw down the finance and at the time of drawing down the finance, because he changed the manner in which he held that finance, he was held to have entered into a new contract and to be unable to take advantage of the investment allowance precisely geared to do exactly what he was doing—reinvesting in his business, creating jobs and expanding. It is hoped that the tax commissioner will not give similar sorts of rulings on this piece of legislation.

How can the tax commissioner make such disadvantageous rulings to a small businessman when he is taking advantage of an incentive of a legally prescribed tax break? Certainly the idea of this legislation is to pick up those who are abusing the system. It is not to put the feet of small business into concrete shoes and push them off the pier.

I suspect that I may be audited after my comments on the tax commissioner, but that is something that small business faces all the time. I want to clearly put on the record for future tax commissioners administering the provisions of the tax act introduced by this bill that the intention behind this bill, from party room to drafting, is that it will not be unduly cumbersome. This is also relevant to compliance costs.

We do not seek burdensome record procedures. In fact, in relation to family trust tax, once the election is made, it is hoped that tax will never be paid, because it is a genuine family trust. They have been in existence for quite some time and have worked quite successfully. It is only when those few seek to take advantage of that tax set up that we run into problems.

Let us have a look at this issue about non‐family members injecting income. They can put 100 per cent in and get 40 per cent out. That sounds like some kind of tax break to me. I do not quite grasp the point made by the member for Wills. Normally, those sorts of injections of income come when the trust is running at a loss. Given that it will be taxed if it is distributed to non‐family members, I do not see the relevance of that particular amendment. I also encourage the tax commissioner to interpret family members in a broadly defined way, similar to the way in which distributions will be broadly defined. Again, I think people like stepchildren need to come within that sort of definition but, again, it is up to the tax commissioner.

As for the Medicare levy, it is only reasonable that once income is drawn from a trust for personal use, tax is paid on it. And if the relevant Medicare levy is required, then that is imposed, too. Quite recently we introduced a superannuation bill where that superannuation surcharge will be applicable to us as parliamentarians. We seek to be even‐handed and right across Australia with this stuff. If you are eligible for that extra Medicare levy because of your income capacity, then it is only fair that you should pay it if you are gaining your income by way of a trust.

How are we going to afford the health standards in Australia with an ageing population and, therefore, more users for the government to support, and with a failing private health system and again, therefore, more users for the government to support? I have many friends in the medical area and I talk both to workers in the Nepean and Westmead hospitals. We need tax reform to support a health system left on a precipice by Labor. Waiting lists have blown out according to today's Daily Telegraph, which describes a `tenfold rise in elective surgery lists' in New South Wales. The Sydney Morning Herald states:`the queue for surgery keeps growing'.

Something must be done about this. Positive tax reform that takes into account the needs of small business and the requirement for business in Australia to be able to make a profit to reinvest in this country and have some incentive to do business here and create permanent jobs is what it is all about. I have no hesitation in saying that we have made the right amendments to this bill. As distinct from Labor's proposition, this makes it a workable document for small business in this country. I commend the bill to the House with that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis, Ralph, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the second reading amendment read by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans). Of course, that second reading amendment refers to the House expressing serious concern about the government's action in delaying the introduction of this important legislation, and it also expresses concern about the changes that have been made to the Labor legislation of 1995 in regard to family trusts. I will come to both of those issues.

SPEECH.PARA: One must ask at the start: just where has this legislation been? This was announced by me as the Treasurer in April 1995. It was introduced into the parliament in September 1995. It was then sidelined by the Senate, so it was part of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995. The rest of it got through, but this part was sidelined into a committee and effectively eliminated from being put on the statute books because with the calling of the election in February 1996, the legislation lapsed.

The new government announced in the budget in August 1996 that it would proceed with modified measures. In February 1997 they gave us an exposure draft of the modified measures and then in May 1997 in the budget, they announced further modified measures. Now, in October 1997, the legislation is finally introduced into the parliament. We are talking of a mammoth delay here. This government can hardly be accused of rushing legislation. Indeed, it has taken 19 months to produce amended legislation.

Even allowing for the need for them to reconsider the bills, for public discussions of their proposals, this is surely an inordinate time. And that is important, because what we are talking about here is not minor dollars. We are talking about $550 million of tax which is currently being avoided. It is a large amount of money. Yet this government has been dragging its feet in bringing this legislation to this House. One asks the question why. I think the deputy leader of the opposition, in his second reading speech, gave a pretty good answer as to why there has been this delay.

I will just go back for a moment to refer to the need to act against trust losses. I remind the committee that, prior to these measures, losses incurred by trusts could generally be carried forward to offset income in later years and that there was no restriction on the period of the carry forward. This placed trusts in an advantageous position in comparison with companies. For companies to carry forward losses, they had to satisfy a continuity of ownership test or a continuity of business test. Trusts are not required to satisfy any such tests, so a trust could have changed in its composition or dealt with different matters or different business but still be able to carry forward the losses. So trusts are wide open for trafficking in losses.

Where you have a trust with prior losses but little income—that is, the trust is not able to access the full value of the allowable deductions from the losses—and there is another trust with sufficient income to be able to offset the prior losses of the deficient income trust if it acquires those losses and so use them fully for tax deductions, it is then in the interests of both of the trusts for them to do a deal, to come to an arrangement, so that they can have the full utilisation of the losses with advantage to both parties—but a disadvantage, of course, to the national revenue.

The revenue estimates for this measure—over half a billion dollars, as I have said—show the extent to which this tax loophole is being used. This is a substantial tax loophole that must be shut. The 1995 measures sought to block this tax loss by placing trusts in much the same position as companies in regard to prior year losses, except that the continuity of business test would only apply to corporate unit trusts and public trading trusts; an income injection test would prevent a deduction for prior losses where income or other consideration was injected into the trust by outsiders to take advantage of the loss; and there were to be special rules for family trusts and discretionary trusts so that family trusts would be able to deduct losses, provided that members of the same family were the only persons who could benefit from the trust and it passed an income injection test. That was an important element in the 1995 measures that we proposed—the family trust had to pass an income injection test.

As is now history, these measures did not get through the Senate, so we are now faced with this new legislation after these modifications. The main difference, as I have said, is in relation to family trusts—that is, the income injection test will not apply to family trusts where the income or consideration is injected into the family trust by entities or individuals within the family group.

Even though the original definition of the family group has been narrowed in this legislation, there is still a very big potential loophole that is being left in the tax net in the area of family trusts. So, as against the definition of family that was in the 1995 legislation, we now have a narrow definition but, because of the elimination of the income injection test requirement, there is, in our view, considerably enhanced scope for tax avoidance in family trusts compared with the 1995 legislation.

In narrowing the family group, this legislation eliminates former spouses, great‐grandparents and aunts and uncles from the family group, but it still leaves parents, grandparents, brothers, sisters, nephews, nieces and children. There is plenty of scope there to take advantage of the non‐application of the income injection test, particularly so in the case of very wealthy families with multiple financial interests, all of the family presumably having substantial interests and, in many cases, numerous interests and certainly being capable of injecting income into a trust that has substantial losses.

My concern about this goes back to the advice that I received from the tax office and the Treasury about family trusts in late 1995 and early 1996. This advice to me, as Treasurer, from the tax office and the Treasury, pointed out, in the context of drawing attention to the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars in tax revenue by high wealth individuals through the use of trusts and other devices, that family trusts are used by high wealth individuals as part of their tax minimisation arrangements and that any reforms should not exclude all family trusts from their ambit.

In relation to the trust loss measures in particular, the tax office and Treasury twice expressed their concern to me about the rejection of the 1995 legislation in the Senate, saying that the trust loss measures were an essential part of dealing with the taxation of trusts of high wealth individuals and that the efficiency of the trust loss measures in the 1995 legislation was complicated by the fact that they contained concessional treatment for family trusts already in the 1995 legislation. They said that most of the mischief involving high wealth individuals is found in discretionary family trusts. I re‐emphasise that point: the tax office and Treasury were saying to me that most of the mischief involving high wealth individuals is found in discretionary trusts. The tax office and Treasury were therefore concerned that the government was being told that the category of family trust was defined too narrowly and therefore the implication—from others, not from the tax office and Treasury—was that we should be expanding the definition. They were expressing their concern about that.

The tax office and Treasury later advised me that the family trust concession introduced into the 1995 legislation was a very significant concession, since it effectively meant that there could be tax loss transfer and income streaming within a family by use of a family trust. In other words, they were saying that by allowing the family to deduct losses within the family trust, you are enabling them to transfer losses around within that group and stream the income according to who can pay the least tax et cetera. That is a very substantial concession and most of the trusts used by high wealth individuals could be loosely described as family trusts. A family trust concession in any broader legislative change could seriously undermine the effectiveness of these changes. And I re‐emphasise that. The tax office and Treasury were saying to me that a family trust concession in any broader legislative changes than those we had already had in the 1995 legislation could seriously undermine the effectiveness of these changes.

Those were very strong words that were being put to me by my advisers then, the tax office and Treasury, about the dangers of further weakening this legislation. Clearly, the tax office and the Treasury were concerned that expanding the scope for family trusts to be able to utilise prior losses would allow the continuance of a substantial level of tax avoidance through this avenue. That, of course, is exactly what this legislation now before us does. It does exactly what the Treasury and tax office were saying to me should not be done. Despite narrowing the definition of the family, as I have mentioned, by simultaneously removing the income injection test for members of the family, this legislation allows a wide‐open avenue for tax avoidance, especially for very wealthy people who are capable of injecting other income into a family trust to take advantage of any losses in that trust.

Given their advice to me, I would be very surprised—indeed I would be astounded—if this modification of the 1995 legislation has the support of the tax office or the Treasury. Indeed, I would say that this is a reason why it has taken so long to come to us—because of a struggle about this legislation coming forward in this form.

But I must say I am not surprised by the approach taken by the government. The coalition parties' actions in opposing the 1995 legislation in the Senate showed where they were coming from. Certainly, the leisurely pace of activity to address this problem since they gained office does not denote a driving zeal to block tax avoidance in this area.

Let me remind the committee of what I announced in February of 1996, when we released the information that had been given to us recently by the tax office and Treasury about tax avoidance by high wealth individuals, and particularly through the use of trusts.

I will just paraphrase parts of this press release. In it I said that I had been advised by the tax office and Treasury that in 1993, 80 individuals each with a net worth of over $30 million had returned taxable incomes of $20,000 or less—not paid tax of $20,000 but had taxable incomes of $20,000 or less. That enabled them to qualify for low income rebates, Medicare exemptions, deferral of HECS payments, reduced child support payments, et cetera. By 19 January 1996, the Treasury and the tax office were able to advise me that on the basis of work undertaken on 100 wealthy individuals, they expected that action to block these tax minimisation techniques would raise at least $500 million, and they later raised that to $800 million.

In the press release I also said that the tax office identified a number of complex tax planning arrangements used by some wealthy individuals to avoid tax and these included: the characterisation of income as capital by the use of multiple trust structures to conceal a common controlling mind, and the tax office had found a number of cases of wealthy individuals operating over 100 trusts; the creation of artificial losses, revenue as well as capital, to neutralise otherwise taxable profits; distributions to wealthy individuals and family members being disguised as loans and other benefits which are claimed to be non‐taxable; the continued use of offshore trusts to hold significant funds which seemed to be applied for the benefit of wealthy individuals and their families; and the use of Australian charitable trusts and overseas organisations to disguise benefits provided by family trading trusts to family members.

I went on in that press release to state that on 29 January 1996 I wrote to the Secretary to the Treasury and to the Commissioner for Taxation asking them as a matter of urgency to develop a legislative response to cover income for the 1996‐97 financial year. I asked as a matter of urgency, and I asked for that in January 1996. Here we are in October 1997 and we have not had any response. We have not had any response, effectively.

The then opposition leader and now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) reacted to that press release of mine by saying that he was sceptical of the monetary estimates, although they were provided by the tax office and by Treasury, they were not my estimates. He also described the amounts estimated to be avoided as fairyland. This did not seem like the response of a man who was determined to stamp out tax avoidance, and his government's inaction in office in relation to this area would only confirm that initial impression.

There has been some action taken in areas such as charitable trusts, in thin capitalisation which relates to companies and trusts and the watered down approach to trust losses now before us, all areas identified by Labor as needing to be addressed, but what of all the other areas I have pointed to on advice from the tax office and Treasury being utilised by high wealth individuals? Nothing concrete has happened at all.

Certainly, earlier this year there were reports of further investigation by the tax office into another 100 wealthy individuals and there were various press reports about this. One was in the Financial Review of 24 February 1997 headed Tax Office's new rich hit list and quoted the tax commissioner as saying:
The integrity of the tax system relies on us dealing with this.
He must be getting pretty desperate indeed.

Then, in the budget the government announced it would release a discussion paper prepared by the tax office and Treasury outlining relevant tax issues and broad policy issues for the appropriate taxation of trusts. Although this was announced in May, we still have not seen this discussion paper. The government claimed it would be in a position to consider this matter in a legislative way in the context of the 1998‐99 budget, but with no paper yet and time needed for public consideration and submission to government, and time for the government to decide what to do, if anything, it is starting to look doubtful that we will see any action in next year's budget.

Clearly, this is not a government which is highly motivated to take effective action against substantial tax avoidance. My advice was that it would take about six months to prepare legislation, but here we are almost 20 months after the change of government and we have not got a discussion paper let alone some legislation.

I am pleased to say that is not stopping the tax commissioner from raising some issues of his own. In a speech to CEDA in Adelaide on 10 September 1997, the tax commissioner made some very worthwhile points indeed. He said in the course of this speech:

Both companies and trust structures can offer the advantages of limited liability and a capacity to split income (even more in the case of trusts). In these circumstances we think it is perfectly valid to raise for consideration the question "why should not the starting point for this be that companies and trusts be treated the same as tax purposes". Thus, for example, we believe it is fair to ask why certain distributions from a business conducted through a trust are capable of being received free of tax while the same distribution made from a business conducted through a company is subject to tax.
That is a very good question indeed, and I am pleased to see him raising the issue publicly. He went on in that address to refer to the high wealth individuals and tax avoidance and noted:

In excess of 2500 entities have been found to be associated with around 100 wealthy individuals examined in some detail. These entities include around 550 discretionary trusts, 230 unit trusts and 20 charitable trusts.
This is for 100 people.
We have not fully analysed the use of these entities or whether they are necessarily tax motivated.

However our examination does reveal that during the l995 income year alone the total amount of tax free distributions from reserves to beneficiaries of the trusts was around $50m. In one case, an amount of $19m was distributed to a wealthy individual. In another case, a wealthy individual received distributions of $5m per annum over at least three years from trusts.

Arguably these results may be within the law. But to the extent they are it demonstrates in quite graphic terms the impact of the distinction in treatment for tax purposes of business activities conducted through trusts as opposed to companies in general and a differing treatment of distributions in particular.

It is clear that in that address the tax commissioner was putting forward a view that there is a substantial case for taxing trusts like companies. However, once he had made that point, two weeks later the Prime Minister was reported as telling his government party room, when he was asked in the party room about this issue of the taxation of trusts, that the party would not be doing anything that would bankrupt small business. Again, he seemed to put a damper on it, and the press reports were along the lines of him having slapped the tax commissioner down.

It would appear that this government is at odds with its advisers on anti‐tax avoidance measures and, therefore, unable to take effective action in this area. Nevertheless, we look forward to the discussion paper, and some eventual legislation in an area that is crying out for amendment to protect the revenue from rampant avoidance practices and to remove the absolute obscenity of extremely wealthy people being able to arrange their affairs within the law so that they pay little or no tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always useful to follow the member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), who has considerable experience in this area. I do not intend for one moment to hold myself out as an expert either in tax law or in legislation relating to avoidance. I remember doing tax in l980 when I was at law school but that is about the only thing I do remember about it, thankfully. Having said that, my very quick understanding of this legislation is that I do not have terribly much understanding of it because it is extraordinarily complex legislation. There are 140 pages involved and 186 pages of explanatory memoranda. I have one principal objection to it, which concerns me greatly, and that is the element of retrospectivity.

SPEECH.PARA: In effect, a press release was issued by the honourable member on 9 May l995, and 2½ years later we are considering legislation that will have an effect on people who have lodged tax returns in those years past. I say right at the outset that I am fundamentally opposed to the notion of retrospectivity and I think that in this particular case I am going to have great difficulty supporting this legislation for that very reason. I am particularly attracted to some of the flaws that have been raised in relation to this legislation.

I say right at the outset that I do not have a family trust myself, and I do not support people who avoid tax—and I do not think it would be terribly easy for anybody to do otherwise. I have no truck whatsoever with anybody who is avoiding tax on the grand scale outlined by the honourable member for Gellibrand. Obviously, all of the professional bodies, such as the NTAA, have accepted the need to prevent trafficking in tax losses.

But the problem is that the legislation goes much further than that. It goes beyond that. That is a real problem I have in terms of retrospectivity, because you cannot have legislation by press release. You cannot purely point to a press release and say, `It is not really retrospectivi ty. See that press release? We said'—as did the previous government—`that we were going to prevent the trafficking in trust losses.' It really is an unacceptable proposition to do so, because it creates the potential for precedents across a number of other areas.

I am concerned to say this carefully: if you open the door in any area of legislation to this principle being diluted, it can be diluted across the board, and that is of great concern, particularly if there is any reliance on a press release to say that in reality people were put on notice. They were not put on notice to 140 pages of legislation and 186 pages of explanatory memoranda as at 9 May 1995.

The concerns I have are for my small business constituents in particular, people who may be unwittingly caught up in this legislation. While in one sense I have no difficulty at all in agreeing with the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) that we do need tax reform, it does concern me when the member refers to the largesse, if you like, of the tax commissioner in interpreting what `family' means. The fact of the matter is that this legislation will not apply to great‐grandchildren. You cannot say, `Let's have an expansive definition here of "family"'. It will simply not apply.

I want to give some examples in which it will apply and which, in my view, illustrate how small business can be affected and caught up by this. Look at these two examples. Firstly, A and B each own 50 per cent of the units in a unit trust which operates a nursery business. The business is not going very well and is making losses. Person A decides to get out and consequently sells his units in the unit trust to B. Person B is able to turn the business around and get the unit trust to trade out of financial difficulty. Under the proposed new laws, the unit trust will not be able to claim a deduction for its prior losses even though it and B have suffered the economic effect of the losses. If A and B had been trading through a company instead, the company would have been able to claim a deduction.

Secondly, Mr and Mrs Jones operate a small business through their family company. The Jones family trust distributes income to the company to help cover its operating expenses. In order to receive the distribution of income, the company has had to make an `interposed entity election' under the new proposed laws. Five years later, the Jones family company wishes to expand its business by exporting its products to America. As part of this expansion, 20 new jobs will be created. To finance its expansion, it looks for an equity investor. Under the proposed new trust loss laws the company is unable to expand. If it does take on a new equity investor, any dividends or return of capital paid to that investor will be taxed at the top marginal rate plus Medicare levy. As a result, the company will not expand, and an export opportunity and 20 jobs are lost.
Bear in mind that the press release of 9 May 1995, entitled Trafficking in trust losses, said, inter alia:

The tax law contains tests which limit the deductibility of losses incurred by companies. Their main purpose is to prevent a company with undeducted prior year losses being sold by its shareholders to a purchaser needing a vehicle in which tax shielded income could be accumulated . . .
These provisions do not apply to the deductibility of trust losses.

It has been said by the NTAA that the proposed provisions, as I said before, go way beyond the stated intention. I have mentioned retrospectivity. The complexity is really quite an exercise in contrasts. The ATO, on the one hand, promotes simplified tax laws and, on the other hand, introduces legislation like this.

BREAK.PARA: I state the issue in an example that is fairly contemporary. A trust can last a good number of years—say 80 years. If it is a family trust, under this legislation it can only be distributed to the defendant's family within the categories. It stops at grandchildren. If there is now a one‐year‐old child of that family, 60 years from now he or she will be 61. He or she cannot distribute to his or her children in relation to that trust. Therefore, in my view the definition of family needs to be expanded to extend to great‐grandchildren and great‐great‐grandchildren. It is something that I respectfully ask the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to consider. At the stage we are talking about, where you have the 61‐year‐old, it is almost inevitable that the children will be running the business. But if income is distributed to them, they will be paying tax at the top rate.

Why then can there not be a more simplified situation in relation to tests? The High Court in the Spotless case has held that part 4A has significant teeth to deal with any tax avoidance arrangements that may be able to technically satisfy the continuity of ownership test or same business test, where there has been a trafficking in trust losses, just as it can apply to schemes entered into to get around the company loss rules.

What is wrong with these simple rules with these tests, the same as with company loss provisions? The continuity of ownership test is continuity of control test for non‐fixed trusts and a same business test. There need be no other test because of the law in relation to part 4A and the case to which I have referred.

I have been told by an accountant in my electorate today that the complexity of these new laws will mean that ordinary small business people who have come to him will need to go out and get advice from a fairly expensive lawyer, as well as increased costs in the accountancy business itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot get any cheap lawyers.

—The honourable member for Chifley is reminding me about lawyers' fees, which it would be nice to be reminded about sometimes. It reminds me of a comment made, when there was a very long defamation case running in England and one of the lawyers broke his leg during this case, that there was no truth in the rumour that he did that running to the bank to deposit the fees.

BREAK.PARA: But it is the case, I am told by an accountant in my electorate, that this will mean more complexity and more costs for small business people. I have no problem about dealing with the rorters—and nobody does. Nobody from the NTAA and nobody from the accountancy profession locally in my electorate has a problem with the need to chop out the trafficking in trust losses. But when we go too far—if this legislation has in fact gone too far, as I am advised that it has—in my view, we are hurting the people that we need not to hurt. We are trying to promote small business and we are trying to promote employment, particularly in the examples that I have given.

I would ask the Treasurer to look carefully again—the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) is the minister responsible for this of course—at this piece of legislation, particularly the retrospectivity aspect which, as I said at the outset, I have great difficulty in going along with and, indeed, as presently advised, I do not feel disposed to support.

I would also ask him to look at a more simplified way of looking at these particular measures. Business has been used to company rules for many years. They have worked well—the tougher part 4A provisions and so forth. After looking at those matters that I earnestly put before him, I would ask that some allowance be given to looking at a different way of approaching this, with a view to at least ameliorating the fact that businesses that have lodged returns already will have to have reassessments in relation to their income.

Perhaps the tax commissioner ultimately, because I do not think my submissions are going to change the course of this legislation, could give some relief and exercise some discretion in particular circumstances, having regard to the announcement that was made on 9 May and the legislation that was ultimately produced.

I do ask that these matters be looked at more carefully in the future. It seems to me that, in principle, to be announcing something in May of 1995, to have an election interposed, and then to be considering the legislation in October of 1997, really does give rise to an argument, on the part of those in the community who are affected by this legislation, that it is simply not fair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been suggested, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Trust Loss and Other Deductions) Bill 1997, in a slightly altered form, was originally proposed under the previous Labor government, and I support the measures. In fact, like most opposition speakers, we would seek to have it go a lot further. But I really wanted to initially comment on a couple of statements made by the honourable member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey).

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I found the contribution of the honourable member for Lindsay to be extraordinary. She said that really we should not be taxing the rich, that it was a disgraceful thing that people on social security could be getting more than people who were in the workplace—and I would be happy to concede that as a problem. But if you have a bill that is essentially looking at tax avoidance, that is, people minimising the amount of tax they pay, I just do not understand the causal link to those on social security. That is a most absurd proposition.

She then went on to talk about the situation in Ireland, not about trusts. She said that the Irish government was encouraging some industries. I support that. I think it is a terrific idea. Again, it has nothing to do with fairness and equity in the tax system. Indeed, government speakers have said, `Well, the Labor Party isn't interested in tax reform.' Of course we are. We always have been. Our particular interests are that we believe that everyone should pay their fair share of taxation. It should not just be the PAYE taxpayers—that is, the ordinary working men and women of Australia—who should be shouldering the full burden of income tax. We believe everyone should and, in particular, the wealthiest Australians. Why should they dodge their responsibility to pay a fair share of tax? Of course, family trusts allow them to do that.

Apparently, family trusts are going to be excluded from the purview of this legislation. Indeed, the taxation commissioner is very keen to examine the whole issue of how the wealthiest 100 Australians avoid $800 million worth of taxation by using trusts. Why should some of the wealthiest individuals in Australia receive $1 million, $2 million or $3 million tax free—not for one year, but for several years? How is that fair and equitable? Is anyone going to suggest that workers in your electorate are going to be able to set up a trust to receive their PAYE income and then minimise their PAYE taxation? Of course not and nor can they do it in Lindsay, as the honourable member for Lindsay well and truly knows.

She made a very interesting observation about GST. I presume the honourable member for Lindsay is in favour of GST. She is saying, `Well, services are now going to be able to be delivered on the Internet.' Yes, they are. I make it very clear not only to the people in my own electorate of Chifley but also to people in the neighbouring electorate of Lindsay that I do not support a GST. I do not think it is the highest priority issue in taxation facing this country. I really do believe that the highest priority is returning equity and fairness into taxation and in making the wealthiest Australians shoulder their fair share of the burden.

The contribution of the honourable member for O'Connor was most extraordinary. I am not sure how he was able to get nursing homes into a debate about trusts but he did so very successfully. He made a very offensive comment. He said, `Oh look, when the Labor Party raises the issue of an accommodation bond of some $250,000, they never talk about nursing homes in the western suburbs of Sydney.'

I will talk about nursing homes in the western suburbs of Sydney. It is true that we have Doug Moran nursing homes in the western suburbs of Sydney. For the record, I have had a director of nursing come to me and complain bitterly about one of my federal colleagues. He said, `Can you get her off my back.' He asked me whether I knew her. He asked, `Why was she making these complaints? Doesn't she know that I am a new director of nursing?' One complaint in this Doug Moran nursing home was that patients were being sedated early in the afternoon not because they were stressed or had some psychological or psychiatric problem but to minimise the care. Another complaint was that they were being physically restrained in the afternoon, again to minimise the level of care that was being made.

The third complaint was that they were being fed in the very early afternoon—to avoid overtime or shift penalty payments, obviously. That is absolutely terrible. I say to Mr Moran and his family company of nursing homes: shame on you. This is no way to treat the elderly.

So, yes, we do have a Doug Moran nursing home in the western suburbs of Sydney and I am not aware of one Labor colleague accepting a political donation from Doug Moran. Nor do I know of one former Labor member or senator being employed by Doug Moran. So our hands are not dirty in terms of this nursing home policy. But let me tell you about a couple of the impacts of this accommodation bond in the western suburbs of Sydney. Firstly, we have cut out the capital grants to new nursing homes.

As a member for parliament representing my area, I am very pleased that I have been able to participate in the opening of nursing homes to serve the frail aged in my community. We have a wonderful order of Filipino nuns there. I have the largest number of Australian Filipinos in any LGA in my electorate—Blacktown is the capital—and I believe that when the new census figures come out, it will show an even higher number, twice that of the next government area, Fairfield.

The Australian Filipinos want to set up a nursing home for the frail aged in the Filipino community. It is true that there are not the demographics to justify an exclusive Filipino nursing home, and they do not want to do that. They think that they are able to offer special things in care and pastoral care to anyone who comes to their nursing home. Under the Labor government, if they got approval for a nursing home—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am having some difficulty in relating the honourable member's remarks to the bill that is before the committee: the Taxation Laws Amendment (Trust Loss and Other Deductions) Bill. I would just ask that he tries to contain his remarks more precisely to the bill.

—Let me try to finish up, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I respect the good advice that you are giving me. But I have to be quite honest in that I was really surprised that the member for O'Connor was able to speak at such great length on nursing homes and accommodation bonds. In fact, he offered a challenge that we do not talk about nursing homes in the western suburbs, so I am responding directly to what is in the Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say that those people, the Augustinian sisters, will not get a capital grant, so the impact in the western suburbs of Sydney is this: yes, we have a lot of religious and community nursing homes, but as time goes on because there is no capital assistance, you will not see new nursing homes development in the community and religious sector.

The honourable member for O'Connor said that it is okay, that it is only $250,000, only a quarter of the value of the house. Yes, I am concerned about those who have to sell their houses, but the people that I am most concerned about are those that do not have a house. They do not have assets.

You are going to see a number of things happen. Firstly, you are going to see people dying at home lacking care because they cannot get into a nursing home. Secondly, when they go back to stay with their families because of the level of care they need, you are going to see an increase in the level of abuse of the elderly.

Let me finish on this note. These are not my words but words of senior citizens I have spoken to. You are going to see an increase in suicides as people will not wish to be a burden on their relatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!

—Of course, they will. I went to a senior citizens' function where a well‐respected person involved with senior citizens—I did not invent this—said that she knew of eight couples who had made such a pact. I went to a meeting on Sunday where I was quizzed about your nursing home accommodation arrangements—death taxes, if you like—and a senior citizen, a widow, said to me, `I am not going to go through it. I would rather commit suicide than go through it.'
—You are scaring them!
—The trouble is that you do not like the truth. This is the impact of your policies.
—Order! If the honourable member for Chifley will try to contain his remarks to the bill before the House, it would be helpful to the debate.
—I am happy to, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I appreciate that you would not want to have a double standard, for government members on the one side and opposition members on the other side.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an issue about trusts and about avoidance. As I said before, the Labor Party is always interested in tax reform. We do not believe, for example, that imposition of a goods and services tax is the highest priority because, frankly, a goods and services tax is going to benefit my good friend the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) and myself, and other members of parliament. We will be the ones to get the benefit out of a GST because we have discretionary income. But out in my electorate, with ordinary families and ordinary people, you find that they spend up to the limit of their income every week or every fortnight.

TALK.START.PARA: —So do I!

—Perhaps I need to make a personal explanation here that my wife seems to be a very good deficit budgeter too! But ordinary people do spend up to the limit of their income. Actually raising a family, seeing them clothed, fed and educated, is a triumph for them. They are very proud of it, and if they are able to pay off a home in the process, again, that is a source of great pride. But they do not have any discretionary income to put into savings or to make choices about their expenditure, so they are the ones that are going to feel the real impact of a GST.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike the member for Lindsay, I would like to make it very clear that I am opposed to a GST. I am also absolutely opposed to people who can use trusts to minimise their fair share of income tax. Part of this legislation prevents trusts acquiring the losses of someone else and incorporating those losses into the trust. But the real issue that I think the parliament should be considering is: where is the discussion paper that the Commissioner for Taxation has promised us on this whole issue of trusts and income minimisation? Is the government exerting undue pressure? Are they discouraging the Commissioner for Taxation from producing it?

We have had an example already in the House where the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) does not apologise for wanting to prevent a statutory authority, the Law Reform Commission, from making a submission to a parliamentary tribunal. Do you know the reason? He does not like what the Law Reform Commission is going to say about it. Although in the House today Mr Speaker, in his wisdom, did not give precedence to a breach of privilege, of course the Senate has seen it completely differently and with less material to make that decision. So we do have precedents with this government where, if they do not like the message from the messenger, what do they do? They try to stop it.

All I say to the Commissioner for Taxation, whom I know very well and whom I have a great regard for as a dedicated and keen officer: resist any pressure that may be exerted. We need to clean up the tax act. We need to clean up what is currently legal avoidable income tax. We have to start returning a degree of fairness in there—and not fairness for the wealthy, not fairness for the middle class, but for the ordinary folk who never have any opportunities to minimise the amount of income tax they pay.

Of course, there is the issue of child support. The Australian Taxpayers Association maintains that the bill will adversely affect some people involved in the payment of child support. How regrettable this is. When this government, to its credit, announced some changes and reforms to the Child Support Act, what did they do? They wimped it; they absolutely wimped it. In what was a bipartisan committee report with the now Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) on it, with a now parliamentary secretary on it, with the present president of the Senate, Senator Reid, on it, with a present chairman of a parliamentary committee on it—all from the then opposition side—what do we see the government do? We saw it wimping the opportunity to put a degree of fairness and equity into the child support scheme. Can I say you have sorely let down many people. Indeed, just as that committee was—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. We have had 17 minutes from the honourable member. I know there has been a wide-ranging debate here but other than cleverly using the word `tax' occasionally, there has not been much said specifically relevant to the legislation. I am wondering if you could ask the member to speak specifically to the legislation that is actually before the chamber today.

—I was about to intervene on the member of Chifley (Mr Price). I think that he has had a very wide‐ranging freedom in this debate and I would ask him to return to the bill. If he would participate in that way it would help the debate in this chamber.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure that neither my learned friend or yourself are disputing the press release and its impact on child support. But let me say one of the recommendations in the committee report concerns trusts. In fact there was a whole chapter devoted to repairing the income base. Just as this bill that we are considering is about repairing the income tax base, so it was with the child support report. We proposed that the Commissioner of Taxation, or should I say the Child Support Registrar, wearing his other hat, had the discretion to add in income for child support purposes from the trust.

SPEECH.PARA: I need to make the point that the government ignored those recommendations bar one. Why did you not pick up the trust recommendations? Did you not like the trust recommendations? Why should not income that people derive tax‐free from a trust be counted towards child support? I agree with the Australian Taxpayers Association. Child support is involved with those who minimise their incomes via trusts. In fact, the group of women who are worse off under the scheme have been those women who married men or partners capable of legally minimising their taxation. They have generally received not one cent and of course the government completely turned its back on them. I do not know whether it is part of its small business policy that especially favours people who are allowed to minimise or big business for that matter as well.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I will finish on this non‐controversial note. Let us all be fair. Let us all join together to make sure the rich do pay their fair share and cannot use family trusts, discretionary trusts or fixed trusts to minimise income they should properly be paying to the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, Louis XIV's treasurer, as I am sure you know and as I suspect the member for Chifley (Mr Price) knows, once said, `The art of taxation consists in so plucking the goose to obtain the largest amount of feathers with the least possible amount of hissing.' I am not sure that the member for Chifley got anywhere near addressing that point or even the legislation if it comes to that. But the coalition and the Australian Taxation Office, the ATO, have a long way to go, Mr Deputy Speaker, because their treatment of trust losses has certainly not been met with a minimum of hissing.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset I want to make it clear that while it is generally agreed that changes to the tax treatment of trust losses are long overdue, there is no such accord about the specific nature of parts of this legislation.
Many tax experts understand the ATO's concerns about trafficking in trust losses but as Mr Jon Kirkwood, a partner in taxation at Ernst & Young in Sydney has noted:

The proposed rules go too far and, in particular, may disallow trust losses where a family member beneficiary is included in the trust distribution statement for the first time, even if that inclusion is not motivated by the existence of losses in the trust.
He continued and suggested:
The problem could easily have been fixed by incorporating the company loss rules into the general loss carry forward provisions.

Instead, we are presented with approximately 150 pages of mind bending legislation and explanatory memorandum that would give the Odyssey a run for its money for length and complexity. And all the while the tax law improvement project team continues to toil away at simplifying the existing tax act.

The tax commissioner and the Treasurer assert that the intention of this legislation is to close loopholes which allow individuals `at the big end of town' to avoid paying their fair share of tax. The reality is that this legislation will affect businesses that make a loss, principally small businesses and those from the farming sector.
The point was reinforced in the 22 September edition of Business Review Weekly which said amongst other things:

Michael Carmody is a loose canon operating outside the tax reform debate, flogging the old idea that there is money to be harvested from the rich . . . In the process he is driving a knife into the heart of small business. . .

Official figures reveal that approximately 367,000 trusts were in operation in l994‐95. In the same year an Australian Taxation Office examination showed that the top 100 wealthy Australians were linked to 2,500 trusts. It is absurd for the government to attempt to justify its decision to tax trust losses on the grounds that it is targeting the high-fliers when they account for less than 1 per cent of all trusts in Australia.

Mr John Hallows, a contributor to the business pages in the Sunday Telegraph, made another telling point about the use of trusts in Australia. On 14 September 1997 he noted that for as long as the direct tax base in Australia continues to shrink, and in the absence of a total overhaul of our tax system, the taxation office will continue to look towards tax minimisation and tax avoidance schemes to shore up the revenue.

It stands to reason that until such time as there is parity between the top rate of personal income tax and the company tax rate, Australians will continue to turn to trusts and other devices to maximise their after-tax earnings. This argument was also presented in the 31 May 1997 edition of the Economist magazine. In an article entitled `The Disappearing Taxpayer' it was noted:

Broadening the tax base . . . would allow a much lower rate of tax and therefore reduce the incentive for tax evasion . . . Less complex reporting requirements would reduce another incentive to hide from the taxman.
The government has got a lot of ground to cover on both counts.

Over the past few months, Mr Carmody has provided information to the national media of one or two extreme cases that were intended to bear out his concern that government revenue is being threatened by the use of trusts. Newspapers, including the Australian, the West Australian and the Sydney Morning Herald, reported Mr Carmody's examples of one individual who received a tax-free amount of $19 million in one year and another who got $5 million over three years.

Exactly how the ATO came to this figure is not known but it is interesting to reflect on these calculations in the light of information provided by the Department of the Treasury to the Senate estimates committee on 8 May 1997. Dr Ken Henry was asked:
Do you have any estimates of the revenue lost due to this transfer of trust losses within a group of related trusts?

He answered with an unembellished `No.' I am not sure what part of the word `no' the ATO does not understand. The ATO has continued to suggest, and peddle the line, that changes in the tax treatment of trusts will net the federal government something in the vicinity of, or up to, I am not quite sure, $800 million annually.

Apparently the Taxation Office calculates its sums differently from Treasury because the government's 1997‐98 budget papers estimate a $100 million saving to revenue from its proposed measures. One hundred million dollars is a substantial saving in anyone's book but it is remarkably humble in comparison to that predicted by the Australian Taxation Office. Perhaps it is one of the rare occasions when our Treasurer (Mr Costello) opted to take a dose of modesty pills. Or perhaps, as Mr Kirkwood indicates, it is yet another example of `the bureaucracy looking into a dark corner, not being sure of what it sees, and deciding that a healthy dose of Agent Orange would be simpler than more light on the subject.' If that criticism sounds similar to earlier reproaches about the government's treatment of R&D syndication, it is because it is.

The coalition made it very clear last year that its principal motivation in axing the R&D syndication concession was to stamp out what it perceived to be a rorting of the scheme. It became obsessed with the notion of abuse and yet, to this day, the government has failed to substantiate its claim. Just as the government has shamelessly harped on the notion of tax avoidance by big business, to gain support from the average Australian taxpayer in its decision to axe R&D syndication, it is now seeking asylum for its attack on trusts, on the grounds that high income earners are the target of these measures.

But the motivation behind this legislation is further thrown into doubt by the fact that none of it is necessary for the government to collect its projected $100 billion. At the Senate estimates committee, on 5 June of this year, Dr Henry said:

The $100 million does not depend upon there being any change at all to the taxation treatment of trusts. As I understand it, that $100 million relates predominantly to enhanced compliance activity on the part of the Australian Taxation Office.

If Treasury admits that the ATO has received an additional $19 million in resources to retrieve the sum of $100 million and `investigate the affairs of high wealth individuals', then why has this legislation been introduced at all? It is time that the government came clean on its approach to trust losses. As I have indicated, many tax professionals believe that there is room to improve the integrity of the trust structure. Specifically, deficiencies relating to overseas payments from trusts, and some income splitting arrangements, have been singled out as requiring reform.

However, as recently as 8 May 1997, Mr Simpson, who is also from the Department of the Treasury, made it clear to the Senate estimates committee that the Taxation Office had not conducted any detailed analysis into the constituent parts of family trusts. Nor had it undertaken research to determine the ratio of Australian citizens and residents involved in domestic trust arrangements, as opposed to the number of foreign residents and citizens who benefit from Australian trusts. In other words, the very parts of our current trust legislation that are most open to exploitation have not been the subject of a thorough Treasury investigation. No wonder it has been suggested that the government is wandering blind on the issue. The fact is that the impact of this legislation will extend way beyond Australia's high income earners.

Not only is there a massive discrepancy between the figures being tossed around by the Australian Taxation Office and the government, but the coalition also seems to be unable to provide consistency in its own calculations. On budget night 1997, the Treasurer indicated that it would be almost impossible to forecast the savings to revenue beyond the 1997‐98 year. This was in May. However, the explanatory memorandum accompanying this bill states that the government expects to benefit from the taxing of trusts to the tune of $200 million in the three years ending with 2001. That is a pretty quick transition: somewhere in the four months between budget night and the introduction of this legislation, Treasury has manufactured an additional $200 million in the equation. Where is the accuracy in the guesstimates? The answer is, of course, that there is none.

BREAK.PARA: Trusts are utilised widely throughout the small business sector as a legitimate business structure. While Mr Alan Swan, the education director at the Australian Taxpayers Association, commended the government on some parts of this legislation—as do I—he went on to observe in his press statement of 8 October:
Given that family trusts are one of the most common structures used by . . . small businesses, many . . . will continue to be unfairly treated by the new legislation.
Mr Swan went further:

The government has received numerous submissions from taxpayers and small businesses since 1995, but has chosen to retain (and even add to) some of the illogical and ill‐considered provisions in its latest bid to have the legislation passed.

Mr Swan criticised the government for failing to consult adequately with advisers to the small business sector. Like Ernst and Young, the ATA is concerned that elements in this legislation go way beyond what was originally intended by the government. For example, Mr Swan has criticised those parts of the bill which exclude certain family members from future trust structures. Individuals who are dependants for superannuation purposes and who could have responsibilities under the Child Support (Assessment) Act and may benefit from an inheritance from a deceased estate will not be deemed to be members of a family trust unless and until this legislation is amended.

Mr Swan asserts that the viability of small businesses may be affected, as they will have to decide between `removing key family members from a share of the present or future beneficial ownership of business' or else accept the `potential loss or postponement of legitimate claims for losses incurred during business downturns'. Is this what the government had in mind when it claimed in the explanatory memorandum that the legislation was intended to `improve the integrity, equity and efficiency of the taxation system'? Is it?

The trusts are popular amongst family‐run small businesses, as you very well know, Mr Deputy Speaker, because they avoid many of the related compliance obligations and costs that are part and parcel of a company structure. According to the Business Review Weekly, an effect of this legislation will be that many small businesses will have little alternative but to become partnerships, and will lose their limited liability in the process.

As several independent analysts have recently observed, the wealthy individuals who deliberately employed devious and complex trust arrangements to avoid paying tax will simply put in place alternative but equally devious and complex arrangements to ensure the same end result. The Treasury admitted as much when one of its senior economists told a Senate committee:
It could be the case that no matter what suite of measures might ever be implemented, some part of that, perhaps a large part of it, might never actually be collected.

In its regulation impact statement, the government has made it clear that family trusts will be excepted from the changes proposed in this legislation. It is a welcome exclusion. However, what is to stop the so‐called high rollers from transferring benefits into this type of structure, in order to avoid the tax payable on those trusts that will be bound by the legislation? In the meantime, every small business that is forced to alter its structure as a consequence of this legislation will confront an increased compliance regimen.
In an editorial in the Age on the 15 September, Mr Ross Greenwood asked:
Will the tax officers move truly be a way to reap more tax from the wealthiest . . . or add another impost on the self‐employed?

So much for the coalition's commitment to reducing its impositions on small businesses by 50 per cent in the term of this parliament. The retrospective nature of this legislation will also impact on the compliance costs of small businesses. The collective cost to business to submit amendments to earlier tax returns will be considerable.

There are to be four dates of effect for the measures contained in the bill, all of which will have a retrospective application. Ever since the former Labor government introduced its own trust losses legislation in this place in 1995, tax experts have continued to work under a cloud of uncertainty. How have they been able to correctly advise their clients of the best commercial structure for their business needs? Quite simply they have not been able to and through no fault of their own.

For instance, this legislation will automatically preclude a stepchild from a family trust if his or her parent dies or ceases to live with the test individual of the trust. One of the more alarming things about that provision which has been highlighted by the ATA is that this measure was not announced prior to the 1997 budget. Mr Alan Swan has indicated that this will mean that:

That trustees of family trusts who irrevocably elected to become a family trust before the budget, have inadvertently evicted any stepchildren from their family trust—a harsh penalty for those compliant taxpayers.

The ATA has called on the coalition to amend its legislation to ensure that individuals are not unfairly excluded from a family trust structure. The Law Council of Australia went further than this in its submission to Treasury, when it suggested, amongst other things, that:
. . . the council has formed the view that the current regime covering the taxation of trusts remains appropriate.

On 8 May earlier this year, the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, told the Senate estimates committee that the government does not `claim' to be the champion of small business; they are the champion of small business. Very brave words, Senator Kemp. I wonder how many small business proprietors will agree with him given the government's track record on small business reform to date. It is a disgrace that it has taken in excess of 24 months for the debate on tax treatment of trust losses to reach the parliament. The tax community and the small business sector have operated in an uncertain environment because of the issue of trust losses for far too long.

I conclude by going back to my original position. There is room to improve the efficiency of the trust system. However, the government cannot adequately address this issue without the full knowledge of facts. Even so, if this legislation passes through the parliament intact, it is important to recognise that trusts will remain an effective business structure for many small businesses. However, it is high time that the Treasurer and the Commissioner of Taxation came clean about their approach towards trust losses, that they end uncertainty and that they cease pretending that their sole aim is to target high income earners.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I have had an opportunity to watch some of this cognate debate and it has been fairly wide ranging. Nursing homes took up quite a bit of time for some of the speakers. I know that the member for Chifley (Mr Price) and another member were wide ranging in that respect. Then we have the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) who has just completed and is always very detailed and very interested in these matters.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to make a few concluding remarks. In particular, I would like to make some comments about the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans). He made some quite extraordinary remarks during his contribution to the debate. I just want to refer to some of those things.

The first point he made was that the government had significantly watered down measures to deal in the trafficking in trust losses and had gone soft on tax avoidance. I think this really is quite a remarkable suggestion. Here we are doing something about it and he is suggesting that we have really gone soft on it all.

The legislation before the committee is to restrict the trafficking in trust losses. The coalition committed in opposition to proceed with the measures to address trafficking in trust losses and it has fulfilled that commitment. There can be no suggestion that the government has gone soft in this area. The legislation before the committee demonstrates the government's commitment to pursue legislation in this area. As to the changes announced by the government, those changes have been aimed at ensuring that the legislation is targeted squarely at trafficking arrangements.

The legislation introduced by the previous government was universally condemned as going far beyond trafficking in trust losses. It was suggested by many in the tax professions, and elsewhere, that the original trust loss legislation changed dramatically the taxation treatment of trust losses well beyond what was recognised at the time as trafficking arrangements. Indeed, these criticisms were acknowledged by the previous government when it foreshadowed significant amendments to its legislation in the Senate in December 1995, just prior to the last election.

The Labor Party had itself recognised that its legislation had gone too far and sought to ameliorate its impact. No doubt that is really why the opposition is supporting this legislation here today. They understand that it is good legislation. Even though there has been a lot of blustering about various issues in this debate, essentially the opposition are here and they are supportive of this legislation. The government's legislation is targeted specifically at trafficking arrangements, as the previous government first intended. As for the deputy leader's comments regarding conflict of interest, those allegations really do not deserve a response and I will not be making any here today about that.

In conclusion, I would like to summarise the merits of the changes by the bills. The purpose of the trust loss measures is to restrict the recoupment of losses and other deductions of trusts in order to prevent the transfer of the tax benefit of the losses. This occurs when a person, who did not bear the economic effect of the loss when it was incurred by the trust, obtains a benefit as a result of the trust's ability to deduct the loss.

The proposed measures will prevent a significant erosion of the tax base that would otherwise arise from the transfer of the tax benefit of trust losses. There are no provisions in the income tax law similar to those which apply to companies which effectively regulate the deductibility of trust losses against current and future income.These measures deal with an anomaly in the current treatment of trusts and will improve the efficiency and the equity of the taxation system.

In developing the legislation, the government has undertaken extensive consultation with taxpayers and tax professionals over a lengthy period. I would just like to underline that. There has been a lot of consultation and much of what is in this legislation is a product of that. This legislation therefore does take account of the legitimate concerns of taxpayers while preserving and, in some respects, improving the integrity of the measures.

While the measures will impose some additional compliance costs on taxpayers, this is outweighed by the benefits of improving the integrity, the equity and the efficiency of the taxation system. I would like to thank those people who have contributed to this debate and I commend the bills to the chamber.
Question unresolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —As it is necessary to resolve this question to enable further questions to be considered in relation to this bill, in accordance with standing order 277, the bill will be returned to the House for further consideration.

TITLE.XREF: FAMILY TRUST DISTRIBUTION TAX (PRIMARY LIABILITY) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 1 October, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
