SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Amendment Bill 1997 is to amend the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 which is known in the trade as the SI(S) Act. The amendments will permanently reinstate certain arrangements set out in a number of temporary modification declarations made pursuant to section 333 of the SI(S) Act that were in place up until June 1996. Since that time, the discretionary powers granted to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner by the temporary modification declarations have lapsed. This has serious implications for the retirement incomes of members of superannuation funds which are affected.

SPEECH.PARA: The temporary modification declarations gave the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner the discretion to allow an extension of time for certain superannuation funds to meet the administrative requirements to be considered regulated under the SI(S) Act. Regulation under the SI(S) Act can make a superannuation fund eligible for concessional taxation treatment. Obviously, for a superannuation fund to miss out on this concessional taxation treatment because of an administrative error or an inability to meet a deadline due to special circumstances would be both unfair and unnecessarily stringent and would heavily penalise members of that fund.

Giving the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner the discretion to grant an extension of time is a sensible way of dealing with this issue and, for that reason, Labor is supportive of the measures contained in this bill. It was Labor back in 1993 who established the SI(S) Act for the purpose of ensuring the prudent management and essential protection of the superannuation deposits of all Australians—a most important matter. To date, with very few exceptions, the SI(S) Act has proven to be an outstanding piece of prudential regulatory legislation which has effectively safeguarded the superannuation assets of many thousands of Australians.

The success of the SI(S) Act and, indeed, the establishment of the superannuation guarantee are part of Labor's superannuation record, a record of which we are particularly proud. That is why we treat any amendments to the SI(S) Act with the utmost importance, regardless of how small or inconsequential they may appear to be. If we recall the period prior to Labor's introduction to the superannuation guarantee where only 40 per cent of Australian workers had access to any kind of superannuation, and if we note the extension of superannuation as a result of the superannuation guarantee to 90 per cent of Australian workers, that is a matter that we need to safeguard jealously.

The recent superannuation changes the government has made have caused great concern and a great deal of anguish amongst the public and within the superannuation industry. Labor is listening to the community and understands the frustration that many people feel from the constant changes to superannuation regulation that have occurred since this government came to power. The message that Labor is hearing is that people are sick of having their retirement nest eggs interfered with by a government which moves the superannuation goalposts every time it suits its agenda. As I indicated, Labor is particularly proud of its superannuation record, one of extending access to superannuation from those who were well‐off, across to the broadband of Australian workers, providing opportunities which simply were not there prior to our changes.

For example, on 20 September this year, the government's shortsighted and unfair measure of including superannuation assets in the means test for over‐55s who are in receipt of an income support payment came into force. I have had constituents coming into my own office expressing great concern about how this impacts on them personally. For example, there was a bank teller with the ANZ Bank who had been subject to three armed robberies in the space of 12 months. Not surprisingly, he is no longer a bank teller, and at the age of 55 he has no realistic prospects of getting back into the work force to do something else. He is now expected to access the superannuation nest egg which he had worked for and which was his legitimate entitlement because he is simply not eligible for the disability pension to which he would otherwise be entitled.

He will run down his superannuation over the next few years and become dependent on the age pension. I think that is a completely unfair situation. This is a measure which has impacted on some 67,000 Australians who have had their income support payments reduced, or cut off completely, and they have also have lost access to concession or health care cards. These many thousands of Australians have been effectively forced by the government into early retirement just so that they can access their modest superannuation moneys to replace the income that the government has taken from them. That is simply not good enough. It does not take into account the reality that many over‐55s do not have access to the work force and a realistic prospect of getting access to the work force until their retirement.

Another way in which this government has shifted the superannuation goalposts is through the introduction of the 15 per cent superannuation tax. This is supposed to impact on high income earners, but it will, in fact, impact on low and middle‐income earners. Administration of that superannuation cost has been estimated to cost upwards of $100 million. That cost will be paid for not only by the high income earners that the tax is supposedly catching, but also the many thousands of Australians who earn much less than the $70,000 threshold.

And what about those fund members who do not provide their tax file number to their superannuation fund? Many of those people are also going to end up paying the superannuation surcharge, or superannuation tax, regardless of their income level. So the message that Labor is hearing from the public and the superannuation industry is that people are, regrettably, losing confidence in the superannuation system. The message from people to this government is: stop moving those superannuation goalposts; don't make retrospective changes.

It ought to be said that this amendment does involve a change that is applying retrospectively, back to 30 June last year. That is always something we have to consider. However, on this occasion it is a change which is to the benefit of members of superannuation funds and their members, so Labor is supportive of the retrospective aspect of this bill as well as of the contents of it.

The fact that measures contained in this bill are being applied back some 15 months is evidence that the government is not treating superannuation with the seriousness that it deserves. It is an issue that should have been dealt with around 30 June 1996, rather than 15 months after the provisions have lapsed. However, we welcome the measures contained in this amendment bill. We ask the government to give a lot more serious consideration to superannuation issues in future and to consider more seriously the impact that their changes are having, and will have, on public confidence, which is a crucial part of our three‐pillars retirement income system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The measures contained in the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Amendment Bill 1997 are purely housekeeping ones and, as such, this would have to be the least controversial of all the superannuation bills introduced into this place during the term of this parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose for introducing the principal Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act in 1993 was to facilitate a more prudent management of funds held in superannuation by the administrators of the funds. These safeguards were intended to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of the sensible supervision of the superannuation industry. I was so keen to make that point that I rose first before the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) and caught your eye, Mr Deputy Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted that!

—The SI(S) Act undertook to clarify the obligations of trustees in relation to their superannuation entities. In this way the government of the day hoped to boost national savings and encourage self‐funded retirement by engendering a more positive attitude towards superannuation in the public mind.

SPEECH.PARA: For a superannuation fund to come under the SI(S) umbrella, a trustee first has to elect that the fund become regulated under the act and it then has to meet certain criteria. The fact that a fund must meet a range of requirements to come under the SI(S) arrangements supposedly sets it apart from the funds that do not.

Two recent reviews of the behaviour of trustees confirms the need for them to have to meet specified standards of practice. In May 1997, a Coopers and Lybrand survey confirmed that many investors were receiving a lower than expected rate of return on their contributions because their trustees were electing the wrong funds managers to manage their superannuation savings. The implication from the survey was that many super trustees need to develop much greater expertise in choosing fund managers.

A second report, produced by specialist institutional investment adviser Intech Asset Consulting Pty Ltd, was released in August this year. In the words of Mr Barry Dunstan, a journalist with the Australian Financial Review, it determined that:

Australia's managers of superannuation funds' portfolios are struggling, unsuccessfully, to beat the investment averages and are costing trustees and members of superannuation funds hundreds of millions of dollars a year in underperformance.

Intech's analysis involved funds to the value of $32 million. It has been estimated that underperformance by the erring fund managers translated into a loss of returns of more than $125 million a year for three years—a considerable loss in earnings, to be sure.

SI(S) aims to ensure that trustees take an aggressive approach to investment and that diversification is the key to any trustee's business strategy. In this way, the return to account holders will be maximised without the trustee taking extreme and unnecessary risks.

There are four provisions in this amendment, Mr Deputy Speaker, all of which have been operational for seven years but which were subject to a sunset clause which expired on 30 June 1996. I believe there is agreement between the government and the opposition about the value of these measures because the former seeks to bring them into permanent effect through this legislation and the latter is seemingly supportive of that decision, no doubt influenced by its decision earlier to adopt the very same measure.
There is also widespread support for this legislation within the taxation community generally, as far as I can ascertain. A recent issue of a CCH Tax Week observed that:
This bill contains measures to improve the flexibility of legislative requirements relating to the nature and timing of elections by superannuation funds to be regulated under this act.
The financial impact statement suggests that in maintaining the status quo, these measures will have only a nominal impact on future government revenue.

Three out of the four provisions in the bill relate to an extension of time available to a trustee to have a fund regulated under SI(S). These amendments will mean that a trustee has 60 days from the date that the fund comes into existence to nominate that it is willing to be regulated under SI(S). This time limit can be extended by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner if deemed to be appropriate.

The extension of this provision and the decision to grant the commissioner this power of discretion is entirely supportable. Schedule 1 of the bill also means to provide a trustee with a 28‐day threshold, longer if the commissioner agrees to an extension, to amend an invalid election to be regulated under the SI(S) scheme. Importantly, though, this bill will not diminish the standards that must be met in order for a superannuation fund to benefit from the tax concession offered through SI(S).

Under section 42 of the act a fund will still have to demonstrate that its sole or primary purpose is to provide old age pensions—to use the wording in the explanatory memorandum—thus preventing an erosion of the integrity of the superannuation system. The third effect of the bill will be to allow a superannuation fund that is in the process of being wound up to be regulated under SI(S) even if the trustee has not elected this regulation.

However, the trustee must previously have notified the ISC of the decision to wind up the fund. In this way, Mr Deputy Speaker, superannuation funds will continue to be protected by and receive the tax benefit of SI(S) until such time as the fund is no longer operational. The final amendment will allow the commissioner to extend the time limit for the trustee of a superannuation fund, established before the commencement of the SI(S) Act, to elect that the fund be regulated by SI(S).

As I have already indicated, one of the main aims in formulating the superannuation supervision legislation in 1993 was to consolidate public confidence in the superannuation industry, thereby increasing national savings. The facts are that the majority of Australians remain non‐savers and they remain ambivalent towards superannuation. This has little to do with the performance of SI(S) and much to do with the frequent and ongoing changes to the superannuation system and the availability of government benefits to middle‐income Australia. The companies AGB McNair and AC Neilson released a report six months ago which revealed that less than 50 per cent of the Australian population has any form of savings.

Most people seriously underestimate the level of savings required to provide an adequate retirement income stream and only seven per cent of the community have savings and investments which total more than $100,000, according to that review. A telling point about the scepticism with which many still regard superannuation: the survey found that, outside the family home, most Australians choose bank term deposits over superannuation as the preferred form of saving.

The Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research at Melbourne University also conducted a recent analysis of the attitude towards retirement income in Australia. It found that while the great majority of young Australians expect to maintain financial independence in their retirement this is not reflected in their actual savings behaviour.
The survey found that only one in five people aged 18 to 24 were saving towards their retirement and:
Retirement saving is jeopardised by antipathy towards, and ignorance about, superannuation.
The survey was reported to have found:
The current superannuation system repels or confuses 50 per cent of people, with a third . . . saying they would prefer to pay off their debts rather than add to their super.

During the debate on the superannuation surcharge contributions legislation I noted that since July 1994 there had been a legislative change or Insurance and Superannuation Commission release affecting the operation of superannuation funds once every 6.5 days. That occurred under both Labor and coalition governments.

The superannuation system has been marked by a phenomenal degree of instability for more than three years. It is small wonder that Australians are not flocking to superannuation as the former Labor government predicted they would. The average Australian simply does not have the confidence in the system, nor does the average Australian believe that their superannuation account will not be targeted by government in future tax grabs. At the time of that debate one leading Perth actuary noted:

Everyone working in the industry accepts that there are aspects of the existing system which still need to be improved. This needs to be done gradually to rebuild from the position of uncertainty and distrust caused by this incredible pace of change.
That observations remains true today.

By putting into permanent effect the four measures contained in this bill it is hoped that there will be more certainty and stability in the operations of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act. However, if the government is serious about encouraging Australians to take up superannuation and thereby provide for themselves in retirement then it needs to adopt a more considered and stable approach in its wider superannuation strategies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to get into a debate as to whether Curtin should precede Chifley or Chifley should precede Curtin. It is a matter of settled Labor history but I say to the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), this is an occurrence that I shall not forget too readily!

SPEECH.PARA: Both the honourable member for Curtin and I, as does the opposition, support the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Amendment Bill 1997. I am just a little bit surprised that the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Anthony) is not on his feet adding his support to these measures as well.

I would like to pick up on some of the observations of the honourable member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) and the honourable member for Curtin. It is true that under Labor there were quite a few changes to superannuation, but I have to say that one of the things that we on this side of the House took a great deal of pride in was that we took superannuation from being the preserve of public servants and the preserve of executives in private enterprise and extended its coverage, made it universal, and transformed superannuation for women.

It is interesting that given the rhetoric of the government when in opposition about the importance of national savings, which I concur with, this superannuation measure went a long way to making a real contribution to national savings as well as providing for people in their old age.

It is also true that the now government, when in opposition, complained bitterly about quite a number of changes that we made to superannuation. I concur with the view that we really do need to develop a bipartisan approach to superannuation and minimise all these changes. However, I have to place on record my absolute disappointment, and I suppose anger, if you like, at a number of measures that the government has taken.

Firstly, when in opposition, at the last election, they said that the money that the government had budgeted for in forward estimates as a co‐payment to the superannuation of ordinary men and women, amounting to $4 billion per annum, which would have lifted their contributions to 15 per cent over time, has been taken away from them: $4 billion has been ripped out of the hands of ordinary working men and women in this country. That has been very difficult for those on this side of the House to absorb because it is patently unfair, grossly unfair. I think it is fair to say that, luckily for the government, they have not paid a penalty for it as yet because I do not think the enormity of that decision, that broken promise, has hit home in the community.

Another issue is this superannuation surcharge, which is a tax but not a tax. Again, we get accused of only being interested in protecting middle‐class and wealthier people and, of course, that is not the case. The execution of this 15 per cent surcharge will see enormous administrative costs and a messy application. I think it is ironic that in the package of bills that went through yesterday about the 15 per cent surcharge that no‐one could tell us what the impact will be. The actuaries have not worked that out, and particularly, if I may say so, Mr Deputy Speaker, for the superannuation fund that you and I belong to. The real irony is that federal judges and federal politicians will be paying it but we do not know whether state politicians and state judges will be paying it. I would be very interested to hear the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) elucidate and fill in that knowledge gap that I have.

I think these two measures are very draconian. I have neglected to say that, given the changes that are occurring in the economy—that is, the rate at which we are shedding full‐time jobs and replacing them with part‐time jobs—those people who are receiving a superannuation payout, on modest incomes are, of course, being caught up in the surcharge. So ordinary men and women are being caught up in the surcharge, not just those who earn over $70,000. I think that change is to be very much regretted.

I think what the honourable member for Curtin said is true: people are now starting to opt out of superannuation. In fact, it is much better for someone like you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to be negative gearing and putting assets or money aside, and getting income from those sorts of things rather than from superannuation. I think that is regrettable. I think it is regrettable that all you will be getting now is about a three per cent return on superannuation. In terms of superannuation, instead of seeing a steady climb in the value of the nation's accumulated savings, we will be seeing it doing a turn. This is quite contrary to the rhetoric of the government when in opposition—that was, emphasising the importance of national savings and personal savings. It also means that, in an ageing population, rather than the pension becoming a safety net for a decreasing number of older Australians, it will increasingly be drawn on.

As the member for Chifley, it would be remiss of me not to point out that the actions of the Howard government in relation to superannuation mirror precisely the actions of the Menzies government in relation to the changes that Chifley introduced in terms of the national welfare fund. Here was a fund every working Australian had to pay into, and it was shown separately from income tax. I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, that when you talk to pensioners in your electorate they will remember the national welfare fund and will tell you about it. They will get very stroppy when you talk about an age pension, because they quite rightly say, `We contributed to that out of our earnings.'

But what did Menzies do? The first thing he did was to abolish the separation: that is to say, people would not be shown their contributions into the national welfare fund separately from the income tax they were paying. Then, of course, he had the money go straight into consolidated revenue and left the national welfare fund as a mere shell, with no money in it at all. It is not surprising to me, although it deeply grieves and saddens me, to see that some really key changes that the Howard government has brought in have destroyed some of the good work that we had done in terms of superannuation.

In the very short time left to me, there are a couple of things I want to say. One is that on the Labor side, of course, there is always a debate about whether, in terms of their fiduciary responsibility, the directors or the trustees of a superannuation fund should always go exclusively for the best interests of their members—the highest return for their members—or whether it is more appropriate to encourage superannuation funds to devote some of their money to developing innovative industry that will sow the seeds of a real future for Australia: buying some of the economic farm back.

I would always argue that the first duty of the trustees is to ensure that the fund itself is very sound and well managed. But I do say that governments, whether conservative or Labor, have a responsibility to see in what way they can encourage a portion of those funds to be going into what could certainly otherwise be called a slightly higher risk than their traditional blue chip investments are. I must say that, in talking to workers on the factory floor or in retailing or whatever, I find they are quite comfortable with the idea that some of their funds should go to promoting Australia.

Last but not least, the opposition is looking forward to seeing the Wallis reforms and legislation being enacted and to seeing how the prudential supervision of banks, credit unions, superannuation companies and insurance companies is going to operate. No doubt we will be seeing, in the new year, changes to the very legislation that we are now enacting.

But I have to say that from my perspective I am not convinced that, whether in banking, insurance or superannuation, we have got everything right in terms of consumer protections and the ability of consumers to make legitimate complaints against their funds and to have those funds' actions fully examined. Certainly, as a federal member, I have had dealings with the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, and they have been very helpful in terms of the cases that I have brought to their attention. But I cannot say that I am satisfied that consumers have, under either us or the new government, the full protection that they deserve.

I also think that there is an issue of accountability here, so that the trustees or directors of a superannuation fund do report to their fund contributors. It does not matter whether we are talking about banks or superannuation companies or insurance companies: I am one who believes that there ought to be a public process of accountability whereby not only individuals but also organisations that are formed to represent individuals have an opportunity to cross‐examine these funds, banks or insurance companies about their actions.

When the Wallis legislation comes before the House, I, as one member of this House, will be taking a great deal of interest to see not only how the prudential and fiduciary responsibilities of these organisations are provided for in the legislation, but will be watching the public accountability of these organisations. After all, they do husband the savings of a nation and the consumer protection that is provided in it.

I have say I do not believe merely giving coverage ACCC to look at the operations of these organisations is providing adequate consumer protection. I mean no disrespect to ACCC, whom I was corresponding with quite recently. But why they have the `C' representing consumer in their name is beyond me. I think it is a complete misnomer. It is very confusing to the public and very little of their operation really has to do with consumer protection. In conclusion, we are supporting this legislation, even though the government appears not to have speakers in support of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I just want to make a few brief comments in summing up and to challenge the opposition on whether the superannuation industry is still growing and being an effective instrument for people putting in their savings. The opposition have indicated that really superannuation has lost its edge as a place for investing in and that somehow we might be wrecking this. I am reminded of a quote on May 12 by Senator Sherry about the government. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Every action they have taken, every law they have attempted to enact in respect of superannuation since they came into government, has had the effect of wrecking superannuation, wrecking confidence and wrecking the final payout from workers' superannuation.
Yet the empirical data is that $1 billion every week has been going into superannuation for the last year up until June l997.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that as a year on year increase?

—As a year on year increase, 20 per cent during l996‐1997. That is a pretty big increase. It is over $304 billion now and about $60 billion went in during the last year. That is a huge investment into superannuation. I just do not think we can actually say in any respect that the action taken by this government is wrecking superannuation when people are voting with their feet to put money into the superannuation schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: You could tease this out a little bit. When you have a look at who is putting in, the strongest growth came from member contributions, not from the employers. They increased by 17 per cent, whereas employer contributions increased by 10 per cent. I think Australians are voting with their feet. They are confident about the management of the superannuation industry by the present government. I just wanted to make the point very strongly.

There is growth. Australians are still involved in superannuation. The member for Chifley (Mr Price) indicated that there was considerable growth into superannuation while his party was in government. That is true. I remember someone quoting yesterday—and you should have been down there in the debate yesterday to find out the information. From 40 per cent of the population to 90 per cent or something like that has been quoted.

BREAK.PARA: I think all of us in this place would welcome that people are now involved. But I want to say here that not only did that increase occur but it has been maintained in the way in which people are being involved in superannuation. I just want to make that point.

The member for Chifley did ask some question which related to the debate yesterday, but seeing this is a very pleasant debating chamber, I will answer that question here. That is that state members will be taxed on the 15 per cent surcharge and those incoming state judges will also come within the ambit of the 15 per cent surcharge—not the present judges, just like the present High Court judges, but the ones coming in. That is the answer to that question.

Just in summarising, there was also another query about why it has taken the government 20 months to bring this legislation in. Can I just say that there was legislation which was brought into the parliament in the spring of 1995. It was passed at that time but this was not part of that legislation. I do not think the present opposition have any room to complain about the government actually bringing this legislation in now. It has been given a T status for getting this legislation through. It does have a priority.

I do welcome the opposition's support for these measures and the recognition of the importance of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act in regulating the conduct of the trustees of superannuation entities to ensure prudent management of superannuation moneys. This amendment bill will provide more flexibility in the administration of the election of provisions under the superannuation legislation. The measures are necessary to respond to the expiry of discretionary powers and ensure superannuation benefits in otherwise complying funds are not eroded through the loss of taxation concessions. I commend this legislation to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I open the debate on the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997 and the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 for the opposition and indicate at the outset that I propose at the conclusion of my remarks, which may well be tomorrow rather than tonight, to move formally a second reading amendment which I am happy to have circulated now. I have taken the opportunity of alerting the responsible minister, the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer, of the amendments, so I hope he has had some notice of them as well. I have also indicated that when this bill is returned to the House I am proposing to move an amendment in the committee stage to effect the thrust of the second reading amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997 and the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 facilitate the corporatisation of the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐electric Authority, as agreed in 1995 between the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victorian governments. The corporatisation thrust of this legislation had been agreed by those on this side when we were in government and, as will become clear in the course of members hearing my remarks and reading the proposed amendments, it is not the corporatisation thrust of the legislation with which the opposition has difficulty.

The rationale for the corporatisation of the Snowy Mountains Authority was outlined by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) in the second reading speech; in effect it will enable the authority, under its new corporate entity, Snowy Hydro Ltd, to participate fully in the emerging competitive national electricity market. This, of course, is an important thrust to ensure a national electricity market, to ensure competition amongst energy sources. This has been part of a general thrust which on this side of the chamber we have been engaged in since as early as 1990‐91 to bring more effective national focus and competition to our energy sources.

The nature of the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐electric Authority is that complementary legislation is required in the Victorian and New South Wales parliaments and that has occurred. The Victorian legislation is expected to be passed by the Victorian house in due course. The New South Wales legislation has unfortunately fallen foul of those things known as upper houses which, with the greatest of respect to our colleagues, no self‐respecting member of the House of Representatives has much time for.

Having said that, from time to time, some minority members can come up with a reasonable report, and I will refer to that subsequently. An amended version of the New South Wales legislation is expected to be introduced into the New South Wales parliament later this year or early next year. The structure of the legislation is that the Commonwealth legislation cannot be proclaimed until the complementary bills are passed in those jurisdictions and an independent water inquiry on the water flow of the Snowy has been conducted. It is that aspect which goes to the heart the amendment, which I will move in due course.

The bills terminate the existing legislative arrangements in relation to the Snowy scheme and form a new company, the Snowy Hydro Ltd. The Snowy Hydro will manage and operate the Snowy Mountains scheme and the Commonwealth and two state governments will have shares respectively in the new company—New South Wales 58 per cent, Victoria 29 per cent and the Commonwealth 13 per cent. The charter given to the Snowy Hydro Ltd is to generate electrical energy and market that energy and related service on a strictly commercial basis in the national electricity market.

To digress from the objects and purpose of the legislation, this is consistent with the thrust to bring competition to our energy sources. It is not just gas on gas. It is gas on electricity and it is electricity on electricity irrespective of the way in which electricity is generated whether that be hydro, coal, gas or co‐generation.

To continue with the Snowy Hydro's principal purposes, it is also to operate on a financially viable basis in accordance with the corporate plan approved by its members and to undertake any future developments and operations that are commercially viable and that are agreed by the board.

BREAK.PARA: So far as transitional arrangements are concerned, one thing which is always important on this side of the chamber is that all current Snowy Mountain Authority staff will be offered transfer to Snowy Hydro Ltd with no net loss of their benefits or their entitlements. In addition to that, the corporatisation process will enable the facilitation of repayment of substantial debt owed by the Snowy Mountains Authority to the Commonwealth.

Because of the nature of the geography of the Snowy, Snowy Hydro Ltd will be governed by New South Wales law and the obvious and relevant laws are those in respect of planning, water and the environment. The heart of the thrust of the amendment which I foreshadowed goes to the conducting of a water inquiry into the Snowy water flow. While the Commonwealth legislation does not expressly provide for it, corporatisation principles which have been agreed between the Commonwealth and the states, and which are appended to the explanatory memorandum, provide for the establishment of a public water inquiry under the auspices of the New South Wales and Victorian governments into issues arising out of the current pattern of the Snowy River water flows.

On this side of the chamber, the question of water distribution between electricity, environment, irrigation, aspects or needs had not been resolved by the time we left office. The corporatisation principles which are, as I say, incorporated in the explanatory memorandum, go to the heart of the water inquiry at paragraphs 8.1 and 8.2 of the corporatisation principles. Paragraph 8.2 says:

The inquiry will submit to the States comprehensive, costed options to address the issues considered by the inquiry within six months of its commencement. Thereafter, the States will consider the final report of the inquiry and agree upon a final outcome within two months or such other time as may be agreed by them.

It is the establishment of the inquiry, its outcome and the implementation of its recommendations which are the focus of the amendment. I have kept a watchful eye on the clock, Mr Deputy Speaker. This may well be the most appropriate time to indicate that I seek leave to continue my remarks when debate resumes and, at the conclusion of my remarks, I will formally move the amendment that I foreshadowed.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
